CHAPTER C – TRANSPORTATION

1.0        BACKGROUND

1.1        CENTRAL PICKERING DEVELOPMENT PLAN (CPDP)
           The CPDP was intended to become the guide for the road and transit network for the
           implementation of the Seaton Community. The history of this community planning and
           the status of the CPDP as a Provincial plan approved under the authority of the Ontario
           Planning and Development Act means that while the road network can be reviewed and
           evaluated, the CPDP network is to be given primacy.

           The transportation network including the transit component of the CPDP meets the
           objectives, policies and infrastructure requirements to address the internal network
           requirements for the Seaton Study Area. The CPDP also ensures there is adequate
           inter-regional transportation infrastructure. The CPDP transportation network was
           included in the report as Schedule 4 and is shown here as Figure C1.1.

1.2        CITY OF PICKERING OFFICIAL PLAN
           The relevant transportation goals of the City of Pickering Official Plan ensure that
           transportation, land use and community design plans and actions complement each
           other. In order for the Official Plan to conform to the recommendations of the CPDP, the
           City of Pickering Conformity Official Plan Amendment was endorsed by City Council on
           April 26, 2011. The Conformity Official Plan Amendment revised the Type A, B and C
           arterial roads and added a collector road pattern in Seaton as shown on the City of
           Pickering Official Plan Amendment Schedule II - Transportation System. Schedule II
           reflects the proposed arterial and collector roads as outlined in this MESPA. Schedule II
           is provided in Figure C1.2.

1.3        BACKGROUND STUDIES
           In addition to the CPDP and the City of Pickering Conformity Official Plan Amendment,
           there are several background studies that provide planning and design guidance for
           transportation.

           1.3.1 METROLINX: THE BIG MOVE

           The Government of Ontario established the Greater Toronto Transportation Authority in
           2006 (that was subsequently renamed Metrolinx) to create a long-term strategic plan
           integrating the regional transportation system. A Regional Transportation Plan, titled
           “The Big Move: Transforming Transportation in the Greater Toronto and Hamilton Area
           (GTHA)” was published in November 2008 (a copy can be found at the following link
           www.metrolinx.com/thebigmove/en/default.aspx). The Big Move built on two other
           Provincial reports: the “Greenbelt Plan”, which protects environmentally sensitive and
           agricultural land in the region and the “Growth Plan for the Greater Golden Horseshoe
           (GGH)”, which manages the population and job growth within the GGH.


The Sernas Group Inc., Stonybrook Consulting Inc.   July 2013     Master Environmental Servicing Plan Amendment - Final
SPL Beatty, Bird and Hale Limited, Earthfx Inc.      07161                          Seaton Community, City of Pickering
AMEC Earth & Environmental, R.J. Burnside              C-1
Amos Environment + Planning
           “The Big Move” proposed that GO rail service be expanded into Durham to serve Seaton
           and conceptually identifies a gateway Mobility Hub at the intersection of Brock Road and
           the rail line. ”The Big Move” conceptually identifies service to Peterborough as one of
           many Possible Regional Rail Extensions Beyond the GTHA and suggests as a potential
           longer term project (25+ years) “a new rapid transit service in Durham Region if
           necessary, should the federal government proceed with the proposed Pickering airport.”
           Schedule 1: 15-Year Plan for the Regional Rapid Transit and Highway Network
           conceptually shows the intersection of a number of proposed transit lines at Highway
           407 and Locust Hill. Figure C1.3 shows the original Big Move plan.

           1.3.2 DURHAM-TORONTO-YORK AREA TRANSPORTATION STUDY

           In support of the transportation objectives of the CPDP, the Province undertook the
           Durham-Toronto-York (DTY) Area Transportation Study, (August 31, 2009)
           (www.cityofpickering.com/Seaton/pdfs/DYT_TransportationStudy.pdf), to evaluate long-
           range strategic inter-regional road and transit improvements in these eastern areas of
           Toronto and York Region. Transportation improvements are outlined in the DTY Area
           Transportation Study. The future road improvements are shown in Exhibit 2 and the
           future transit improvements are shown in Exhibit 1 of the DTY Study, shown here as
           Figures C1.4 and C1.5, respectively. The Transit Infrastructure Implementation Plan
           (Table A of the DTY study) and Road Infrastructure Implementation Plan (Table B) are
           appended to this report in Appendix C1.

           In addition to the provincial highways that provide inter-regional linkages, Steeles
           Avenue and 14th Avenue are relevant to Seaton’s transportation needs and are located
           in the City of Toronto and York Region, respectively.

           1.3.2.1           Steeles Avenue East

           Across Toronto, Steeles Avenue serves as a boundary road with York Region but is
           exclusively under City jurisdiction. A 1992 Municipal Engineer’s Association (MEA)
           Class Environmental Assessment (MEA Class EA) study of Steeles Avenue East
           between the Durham boundary and McCowan Road approved a widening to four lanes
           and allowed the City to undertake various improvements along Steeles Avenue. At the
           Durham boundary and across the Rouge Valley, it is generally a two lane road with a
           rural cross-section.

           The Metrolinx publication, “The Big Move”, identified Steeles/Taunton (Project 59),
           between Milliken GO station and downtown Oshawa, as Other Rapid Transit (BRT / LRT
           / AGT) in its Schedule 2: 25-Year Plan for the Regional Rapid Transit and Highway
           Network.”

           1.3.3 DURHAM REGION TRANSPORTATION MASTER PLAN

           The Durham Region Transportation Master Plan, 2005 (TMP) is a strategic planning
           document designed to define the policies, programs and infrastructure improvements
           required to address Durham’s transportation needs for the next 20 years and beyond.
           The TMP reflects the growth and development policies outlined in the City of Pickering
           Official Plan (OP).


The Sernas Group Inc., Stonybrook Consulting Inc.   July 2013    Master Environmental Servicing Plan Amendment - Final
SPL Beatty, Bird and Hale Limited, Earthfx Inc.      07161                         Seaton Community, City of Pickering
AMEC Earth & Environmental, R.J. Burnside              C-2
Amos Environment + Planning
           Preparation of the TMP followed the Master Planning process defined in the Municipal
           Class EA. The work completed in preparing the TMP is consistent with the first two
           phases of the Class EA planning and design process for the proposed Regional Roads
           projects. Regional arterial roads planned to service Seaton are currently being
           addressed in the CPDP Regional Services Class EA Study.

           The    TMP     (a     copy      can    be     found     at    the     following link
           www.durham.ca/departments/works/roads/TMPNov2005.pdf) detailed three coordinated
           and comprehensive strategies to achieve the Region’s Transportation Vision:

                 •     Provide more travel choices;
                 •     Improving the road system; and,
                 •     Mitigating environmental and community effects.

           1.3.4 DURHAM REGION LONG TERM TRANSIT STRATEGY

           The       Durham      Region      Long       Term       Transit     Strategy     (LTTS)
           (www.durham.ca/default.asp?nr=departments/transit/transit_inside.htm)         is        a
           comprehensive plan that identifies transportation/transit challenges and opportunities in
           Durham Region. The purpose of LTTS is to develop a long term regional transit strategy
           that considers multi-modal transportation alternatives as they relate to, and impact
           transit. The report presents the LTTS in a format that complies with Phase 1 and 2 of
           the five-phase MEA Class EA Study process.

           In Seaton, the LTTS identifies Whites Road (Sideline 26), Rossland Road Extension
           (Sideline 22) and Brock Road as key north-south bus transit routes as well as Highway 7
           and Taunton Road as east-west routes with the latter protecting for future Light Rail
           Transit.

           1.3.5 MESP PHASE 1 (EXISTING CONDITIONS)

           This MESPA should be read in conjunction with the MESP Phase 1 report (March 2008)
           which outlined not only the existing environmental conditions for the Seaton Study Area
           but more particularly reviewed and examined thirty-one (31) potential NHS crossing
           locations as discussed further in Chapter C, Section 6.1.

2.0        MEA CLASS EA REQUIREMENTS
           This MESPA provides specific recommendations for arterial and collector roads within
           Seaton that are under the jurisdiction of the City of Pickering. As noted in Chapter A,
           the MESPA functions as a Master Plan / Class EA Study for the City arterial and
           collector roads. Adhering to the Master Plan provisions of the Municipal Class EA
           (Section A.2.7 and Appendix 4), the Seaton Landowners Group has adopted approach
           #2 to Master Planning. In this approach, the proponent undertakes a Master Plan which
           addresses all the requirements of Phases 1 and 2 of the Municipal Class EA and this is
           documented in a report (i.e. the MESPA). Because the City arterial and collector roads
           are subject to Schedule ‘C’ of the Municipal Class EA, they must in addition, meet the
           requirements of Phases 3 and 4 of the Class EA. The MESPA, as a Master Plan, is not
           open to appeal to the Minister of the Environment for Part II Order requests under the

The Sernas Group Inc., Stonybrook Consulting Inc.   July 2013        Master Environmental Servicing Plan Amendment - Final
SPL Beatty, Bird and Hale Limited, Earthfx Inc.      07161                             Seaton Community, City of Pickering
AMEC Earth & Environmental, R.J. Burnside              C-3
Amos Environment + Planning
           Environmental Assessment Act until a Notice of Study Completion for each project is
           issued.

           At the appropriate time, closer to the anticipated date of construction, road projects
           which are subject to Schedule ‘C’ will address the requirements of Phases 3 and 4 of the
           Class EA planning process. Following that study, this process will be documented in a
           Class EA Study known as an Environmental Study Report and a Notice of Study
           Completion for specific projects will be issued.

           The timing of the Phases 3 and 4 Environmental Study Reports for the road projects will
           be established in consultation with the City. City staff will be active stakeholders in the
           Phases 3 and 4 planning process. The conditions of draft plan approval will make the
           completion of the Environmental Study Reports a requirement of the Planning Act
           approvals for the relevant plans of subdivision. It is not necessary to complete the
           Environmental Study Reports prior to development approvals under the Planning Act
           since the completion of these studies will be a condition of draft plan approval.

           The construction of the City arterial and collector roads recommended in this MESPA
           are subject to the provisions of the MEA Class EA as discussed in greater detail in
           Chapter A, Sections 1.0 and 9.0. Depending on the estimated capital cost of the roads
           being planned by the Seaton Landowners Group (SLG), the road may be subject to
           Schedule ‘C’ of the MEA Class EA. For those roads subject to Schedule ‘C’, in order to
           comply with the MEA Class EA planning process, the SLG is undertaking the MEA Class
           EA study in two parts in accordance with the Master Plan provisions of section A.2.7 of
           the Class EA.

           An examination of the City roads proposed in this MESPA (see Figure C6.3) resulted in
           the identification of three road projects which are subject to the requirements of the MEA
           Class EA Schedule ‘C’ 1:

           •     Road I - North-South Type C Arterial (Sideline 24) ($6.77 million)
           •     Road IV - East-West Special Type C Arterial ($5.77 million)
           •     Road VI - East-West Employment Collector ($4.5 million)

           Refer to Chapter C, Section 10.0 and Table C10.1 for the capital cost estimates of the
           City arterial and collector roads in accordance with the definition of “cost” in the MEA
           Class EA.

           The other City-jurisdiction arterial and collector roads to be built by the SLG (which are
           designated to be Schedule ‘B’ projects as a result of their estimated cost of less than
           $2.7 million) are not subject to the MEA Class EA per Ontario Regulation 345/93. O.R.
           345/93 designates only projects listed in Schedule C of the Class EA by private sector

1
 This Class EA Study was initiated using the MEA Class EA, 2000, as amended 2007 with Minister of the
Environment amendments dated March 10, 2010 which adjusted the cost values for municipal road projects.
According to rules set out in the Road Project Cost Limits chart, "the cost threshold in place at the time a project is
initiated shall be the cost threshold used to determine the applicable Schedule and process to be followed throughout
until the completion of the Class EA process". For estimating costs, see also the MEA Class EA glossary. See O.
Reg. 345/93 designating private sector developers of residential development as subject to the Environmental
Assessment Act for Schedule C projects.

           developers as subject to the Environmental Assessment Act; thus, since these road
           projects are subject to Schedule ‘B’, they are not subject to the Municipal Class EA.
           These roads include:

           •     Road II - Type C Arterial (Third Concession Road) between Rossland Road
                 Extension and Whites Road
           •     Road III - North Road
           •     Road V - Collector Road in Northeast Quadrant of Whitevale Road and Rossland
                 Road Extension
           •     Road VII - East-West Collector (South)
           •     Road VIII - Collector Road in Southwest Quadrant of Realigned Whitevale Road and
                 Whites Road
           •     Road IX - North-South Collector (Sideline Road 28)
           •     Road X - Old Brock Collector
           •     Road XI - Mulberry Lane Collector

           While all City roads including the three noted above are addressed fully in this MESPA in
           accordance with Phases 1 and 2 of the MEA Class EA, the three arterial and collector
           roads subject to Schedule ‘C’ must also satisfy Phases 3 and 4 of MEA Class EA prior to
           construction. Subsequent Environmental Study Reports for each Schedule ‘C’ road
           project will be undertaken prior to construction of the road or portions of the road to
           satisfy Phases 3 and 4 MEA Class EA requirements, as outlined in Chapter A.

           The timing for the construction of the City arterial and collector roads which are identified
           in this MESPA were considered in the development of a phasing plan for Seaton called
           the Staged Servicing and Implementation Strategy (SSIS). The proposed SSIS was
           submitted to the City on June 17, 2011 (revised December 2011 and more recently
           revised in October 2012) and provided greater detail about the implementation of the
           arterial and collector roads. The estimated phasing for the arterial and collector roads is
           shown in Appendix C2 (from revised SSIS Figures 2.1 and 2.2).

           The Schedule ‘C’ arterial and collector roads may be further refined via the project-
           specific Environmental Study Reports which will be prepared following the completion of
           the MESPA and prior to road construction.

           Public and agency consultation was carried out for the Seaton Community development
           as a whole and additional opportunities beyond those normally provided under either the
           Planning Act or MEA Class EA, were provided for stakeholders, First Nations, public and
           agencies. As well as opportunities to review the proposed arterial and collector roads,
           the public consultation provided opportunity to review the proposed stormwater
           management plan and recommended community facilities, and to interact with experts at
           the three public meetings. For more information on the consultation undertaken for this
           MESPA, please refer to Chapter H, Public Consultation.

           The Type A and B Arterial roads under the jurisdiction of the Region of Durham are
           being addressed in a separate study entitled “Central Pickering Development Plan
           Regional Services Class EA Study” (CPDP Regional Services Class EA Study). One
           Public Information Centre (PIC) was held for that study on June 16, 2010 and an
           Information Bulletin was issued in January 2011. Please refer to Chapter H for the

           subsequent documentation of the CPDP Regional Services Class EA Study is expected
           to be completed during the summer of 2013.

2.1        PROBLEM STATEMENT – ARTERIAL AND COLLECTOR ROADS
           As noted in Chapter A, Introduction, the existing transportation system of City roads,
           transit, pedestrian linkages, and pathways will not adequately accommodate the mobility
           needs of future residents and workers within Seaton. New roads and transit service are
           required to serve planned urban growth.

           The Seaton transportation and transit networks were established in the CPDP. The
           CPDP provided objectives, policies and infrastructure requirements to address the
           internal network requirements for the Seaton Study Area. It was designed to safeguard
           the NHS by severely restricting natural heritage system (NHS) crossings and to provide
           adequate transportation infrastructure to serve the new Seaton Community. The CPDP
           transportation network is shown in Figure C1.1.

           To a large extent, the location of the NHS crossing of each arterial and collector road set
           the course for the selection of the arterial and collector road alignments. In the
           requirements for the MESP as established by the CPDP, the MESP was to “confirm the
           overall major transportation system requirements, including bridge locations and open
           space crossings and Neighbourhood traffic calming measures” (CPDP, page 27).

           The Transportation Network policies of the CPDP recognized that new arterials would
           require a MEA Class EA study prior to final design. In this regard, the CPDP specifically
           addressed four matters (CPDP, page 56) to be further considered in a Class EA Study:

                 a) “The appropriate location, structure design and intersection spacing for Third
                    Concession Road westerly extension over the C.P. Rail line and West Duffins
                    Creek” [City arterial];
                 b) “The feasibility from an environmental, engineering and cost perspective of the
                    Sideline Road 24 extension north of Taunton Road to the southerly east-west
                    Collector Road” [City arterial];
                 c) “The location and structure design of the Whites Road to Sideline Road 26
                    connection over West Duffins Creek…” [Regional arterial]; and,
                 d) “The appropriate location, structure design and intersection spacing for the
                    Whitevale Road bypass over the West Duffins Creek” [Regional arterial].

           Items a) and b) above are addressed in Chapter C, Section 6.0. Items c) and d) will be
           fully addressed in the CPDP Regional Services Class EA Study.




The Sernas Group Inc., Stonybrook Consulting Inc.   July 2013      Master Environmental Servicing Plan Amendment - Final
SPL Beatty, Bird and Hale Limited, Earthfx Inc.      07161                           Seaton Community, City of Pickering
AMEC Earth & Environmental, R.J. Burnside              C-6
Amos Environment + Planning
3.0        EXISTING AND PLANNED TRANSPORTATION
3.1        EXISTING ROADS
           In the vicinity of Seaton, there are existing Provincial highways and freeways, Regional
           and City roads. The east-west highways and freeways are Highway 7, consisting of a 2-
           lane rural cross-section and 407ETR, a divided toll freeway consisting of two lanes in
           each direction with Brock Road as its current eastern terminus. There are no north-south
           highways.

           Of the Regional roads, Brock Road and Whites Road are north-south and Taunton Road
           is east-west. Other roads are City of Pickering roads, such as Whitevale Road, North
           Road, Third Concession Road (future Regional road – Rossland Road), and Sideline
           Roads 22, 24, 26 and 28. Some sections of the Sideline Roads remain unopened. North
           Road and Sideline Road 24 have overpasses at 407ETR and connect to Highway 7.

           Figure C3.1 shows the existing transportation network.

3.2        PLANNED ROADS
           A combination of Regional and City road projects are planned in and around the Seaton
           Study Area. These are outlined in the following sections. Most of these roads were
           contemplated in the CPDP as shown in Figure C1.1.

           As noted in Section 2.0 of this Chapter, the Region of Durham’s CPDP Regional
           Services Class EA Study will address the Regional Type A and B Arterials within
           Seaton. The Regional roads being addressed include the:

           •     Widening of Brock Road south of Whitevale Road;
           •     Extension of Whites Road (along Sideline Road 26 alignment) to Highway 7;
           •     Widening of Taunton Road;
           •     Extension of Rossland Road to connect with Sideline Road 22;
           •     Realignment of Whitevale Road including the crossing of the West Duffins Creek;
           •     A section of existing Whitevale Road west of Brock Road which will be transferred to
                 Regional jurisdiction; and,
           •     Regional Roads external to the CPDP area to provide an overall Regional roads
                 system within the context of the development of Seaton.

           The remainder of this section addresses the Ministry of Transportation, 407ETR and
           Region of Durham planned roads. City roads are addressed in Chapter C, Sections 6.2
           and 6.3.

           3.2.1 HIGHWAY 407 EXTENSION AND INTERCHANGES

           On June 3, 2010, the Minister of the Environment approved the environmental
           assessment for the 407 East Transportation Corridor (407 East EA) to proceed easterly
           from Brock Road in Pickering to Highway 35/115 in Clarington. A new interchange at
           Brock Road and Highway 407 was approved in the 407 East EA as shown on Figure
           C3.2. This new interchange will require realignment of a section of Brock Road between
The Sernas Group Inc., Stonybrook Consulting Inc.   July 2013      Master Environmental Servicing Plan Amendment - Final
SPL Beatty, Bird and Hale Limited, Earthfx Inc.      07161                           Seaton Community, City of Pickering
AMEC Earth & Environmental, R.J. Burnside              C-7
Amos Environment + Planning
           Fifth and Seventh Concession Roads as well as the realignment of Highway 7, and the
           former providing a bypass of the Hamlet of Brougham. The 407 East EA also included a
           proposed transitway with a transitway station to be located in the southwest quadrant of
           this Brock Road interchange. The construction of the Brock Road interchange is
           anticipated to be completed by 2013-2015 which will coincide with the initial phase of
           Seaton development and the Whites Road interchange.

           The EA approval for the existing 407ETR included two interchanges at North Road and
           at Sideline Road 24. That EA approval anticipated an ultimate widening of 407ETR to
           five lanes in each direction, and a separate Transitway abutting the south side.
           Transitway stations were not included in the EA approval.

           The CPDP proposed to retain the existing over-passes at North Road and Sideline Road
           24, and relocate the proposed interchanges to Whites Road (Sideline Road 26) and the
           Rossland Road Extension (Sideline Road 22). Consequently, the owners of 407ETR
           (407 Concessions Company) will prepare an addendum in order to revise the
           interchange locations to correspond with those proposed in the CPCP and this MESPA.
           Discussions with MTO, 407 Concessions Company, Ministry of Natural Resources
           (MNR), Toronto & Region Conservation Authority (TRCA), the Region of Durham, the
           City of Pickering, the SLG and other stakeholders have confirmed the interchange
           locations taking into consideration the extensive natural heritage and cultural information
           that has been collected for the Seaton area. The addendum to the original Highway 407
           EA will be carried out coincident with the CPDP Regional Services Class EA Study.

           The CPDP (and Terms of Reference of the MESP) required that the SLG consider the
           timing of the two 407ETR interchanges from the perspective of the Seaton Study Area
           and Seaton development requirements. A summary of the factors that were addressed
           in consideration of the phasing of the interchanges is provided in Table C3.1.

           Based on the considered factors, it is recommended that the Whites Road interchange
           at 407ETR be the first Seaton interchange to be constructed.

           3.2.2 HIGHWAY 7 WIDENING

           Currently, Highway 7 east of Brock Road to Highway 12 (Baldwin Street in Whitby) is
           undergoing widening from 2 lanes to 4 lanes. It was anticipated that Highway 7 would
           be transferred to the Region’s jurisdiction upon opening of the Highway 407 East
           extension (originally scheduled in 2014). Highway 407 East is subject to phased
           construction, with the section to Harmony Road, Oshawa expected to be opened in late
           2015 and the final section to Highway 115/35 completed in 2020. Currently, it is
           uncertain as to when the jurisdiction will be transferred.

           MTO has completed an EA Study for Highway 7 between the Markham By-pass and
           Brock Road for minor improvements to this section, however does not include studying
           the provision of widening. In the DTY study, Highway 7 is proposed to be widened from
           2 lanes to ultimately 6 lanes (including HOV lanes) between Markham By-pass and
           Brock Road. Expediting the transfer of jurisdiction of Highway 7, at a minimum, between
           York Durham Line and Brock Road, would permit:

           a) The Region to proceed with a Class EA to confirm the right-of-way and other
              requirements associated with its ultimate design configuration, and
           b) Application of the Region’s planning and design standards which are less restrictive
              than MTO’s and maximize the employment potential.


The Sernas Group Inc., Stonybrook Consulting Inc.                July 2013            Master Environmental Servicing Plan Amendment - Final
SPL Beatty, Bird and Hale Limited, Earthfx Inc.                   07161                                 Seaton Community, City of Pickering
AMEC Earth & Environmental, R.J. Burnside                           C-9
Amos Environment + Planning
           Following the transfer of Highway 7 to Durham Region, this road would be a Regional
           Type A arterial.

           The EA Study for the widening of Highway 7 should re-assess the need for the widening
           to 6 lanes (including HOV lanes) since there is limited ridership potential between
           Markham By-pass and the York Durham Line and inter-regional bus service can be
           provided on 407ETR. This will initially operate in mixed traffic and ultimately on the
           proposed 407 Transitway. Moreover, adequate transit service to the employment lands
           can be provided by Durham Region Transit (DRT) routes in Seaton which will interface
           with the GO bus routes along 407ETR and 407 East at the 407 Transitway stations.

           The latest traffic enumeration show that traffic volumes on Highway 7 in recent years
           have remained stable and that there is residual capacity available. Consequently,
           widening of Highway 7 is not necessary for Phase 1 of the Seaton development.

           3.2.3 REALIGNMENT OF BROCK ROAD AND HIGHWAY 7 AT
                 HIGHWAY 407

           In the vicinity of the Hamlet of Brougham, Brock Road and Highway 7 will be realigned to
           accommodate the new Brock Road Interchange at the proposed Highway 407 East. The
           realignments will be constructed by MTO to coincide with the completion of the Brock
           Road – 407 East interchange which is anticipated to be operational by 2015.

           In the vicinity of Seventh Concession Road, Brock Road is planned to continue along its
           existing alignment. It is anticipated that Brock Road will provide access to the proposed
           Pickering Airport, predominately for freight and air side activities.

           These road section realignments were included in the approved 407 East Transportation
           Corridor EA (undertaken by MTO).

           3.2.4 REALIGNED WHITEVALE ROAD

           For traffic to by-pass the historic Hamlet of Whitevale, a new road was proposed in the
           CPDP. This Type B arterial would travel from the existing Whitevale Road in the vicinity
           of Sideline Road 22 and follow a south-westerly alignment to ultimately connect to 14th
           Avenue at the Town of Markham. This new Region of Durham arterial road was
           included in the Durham-Toronto-York Area Transportation Study and the Durham
           section is included in the CPDP Regional Services Class EA Study. This proposed new
           road is referred to as the “Realigned Whitevale Road” in this document.

           Through analyses completed as part of the Staged Servicing and Implementation Study
           (SSIS), October 2012 it was determined that the need for the crossing of the West
           Duffins Creek by the Realigned Whitevale Road will be in the subsequent stages of
           development. If this occurs, measures by the Region of Durham would be needed to
           protect the existing Hamlet of Whitevale from extraneous traffic infiltration. These
           measures are discussed in the SSIS as follows:

           “Potential alternatives to direct traffic away from the Hamlet of Whitevale include one or
           more of the following:


The Sernas Group Inc., Stonybrook Consulting Inc.   July 2013     Master Environmental Servicing Plan Amendment - Final
SPL Beatty, Bird and Hale Limited, Earthfx Inc.      07161                          Seaton Community, City of Pickering
AMEC Earth & Environmental, R.J. Burnside             C-10
Amos Environment + Planning
           a)          Remove the existing west-leg of Whitevale Road at Whites Road and a section of
                       Whitevale Road east of Golf Club Road;
           b)          Reconfigure the intersection at existing Whitevale Road and Altona Road,
                       perhaps installing a roundabout; and
           c)          Implement one-way traffic along Whitevale Road at the west (westbound) and
                       east (eastbound) links out of the Hamlet of Whitevale. For inbound traffic into the
                       Hamlet of Whitevale, residents would use North Road and a section of Golf Club
                       Road.”

           In addition, as part of the discussions between the City and the Seaton Landowner
           Group relating to certain City financial matters, it has been proposed that the City will
           undertake a separate Whitevale Traffic Management Study that will address traffic
           impacts as Seaton develops on the Hamlet of Whitevale.

           3.2.5 WHITES ROAD - SIDELINE ROAD 26

           Currently, Whites Road intersects with Taunton Road on the west bank of the West
           Duffins Creek. According to the CPDP, Whites Road is proposed to be realigned and a
           bridge added over the Creek to connect Whites Road with Sideline Road 26 at Taunton
           Road.

           At 407ETR, Sideline Road 26 (Whites Road) is planned to have a full interchange.
           North of Highway 7, the Greater Toronto Airport Authority (GTAA) proposed that Whites
           Road connect into the proposed Pickering Airport lands and provide access to a future
           passenger terminal.

           The northerly extension of Whites Road, including a new crossing of West Duffins
           Creek, is being addressed in the CPDP Regional Services Class EA Study. That study is
           also considering the construction of Whites Road from Taunton Road to Highway 7 as
           an ultimate 6-lane cross-section with High Occupancy Vehicle (HOV) curb lanes. This
           segment is needed in Seaton since this north-south road forms the backbone of the
           community for servicing and transit opportunities and will provide access to 407ETR. For
           Phase 1 of Seaton it is proposed that Whites Road will be constructed to its ultimate six
           (6) lane urban configuration from Taunton Road to Whitevale Road except where it
           crosses the NHS and as a four (4) lane rural cross-section road from Whitevale to
           Highway 7. Where Whites Road crosses the NHS between Taunton Road and
           Whitevale Road, consideration will be given to a rural or modified urban cross-section
           provided that the required surface and subsurface infrastructure and transition lengths
           are considered and are appropriate.
           CPDP Regional Services Class EA Study includes the Whites Road widening southerly
           to Finch Avenue.

           3.2.6 EXTENSION OF ROSSLAND ROAD TO SIDELINE ROAD 22

           Currently, Third Concession Road (the extension of Rossland Road west of Brock Road)
           terminates at a cul-de-sac at the former Brock Road Land Transfer Station facility west
           of Valley Farm Road. The CPDP proposes that Rossland Road Extension will extend
           westerly along the existing Third Concession Road and northerly over the CP Rail
           adjacent to the West Duffins Creek and generally follow the existing road allowance of


The Sernas Group Inc., Stonybrook Consulting Inc.     July 2013        Master Environmental Servicing Plan Amendment - Final
SPL Beatty, Bird and Hale Limited, Earthfx Inc.        07161                             Seaton Community, City of Pickering
AMEC Earth & Environmental, R.J. Burnside               C-11
Amos Environment + Planning
           Sideline Road 22 to an interchange at 407ETR, and end at a ‘T’ intersection at Highway
           7 including a grade separation at the CPR right of way south of the first phase of Seaton.

           This road is being addressed in the CPDP Regional Services Class EA Study.

           3.2.7 14th AVENUE

           CPDP and the DTY Study proposed that the Realigned Whitevale Road would connect
           to 14th Avenue at the York Durham Line. The SSIS, October 2012 concluded
           development of Seaton only requires that Whitevale Bypass be extended to Altona
           Road. Possible future extension of the Whitevale Bypass to connect to 14th Avenue may
           be necessary in the future depending on future traffic growth travel demand patterns.

           Class EA studies for the widening of 14th Avenue by York Region are tentatively
           scheduled for 2016 and 2018 for the sections from Ninth Line to Reesor Road and
           Reesor Road to York Durham Line, respectively.

3.3        EXISTING AND PLANNED TRANSIT
           3.3.1 GO BUS

           GO Transit currently operates buses on 407ETR in mixed traffic and eventually plans to
           run them on the separate 407 Transitway along the south side of Highway 407. With
           development of Seaton and construction of the interchanges at Brock Road and Whites
           Road, GO buses will exit the Highway 407 to stop at the combined parking lots and
           carpooling / kiss n ride facilities including transfers to Durham Region Transit (DRT) bus
           routes. This interim condition is referred to as a “transit station”.

           The transit station at Brock Road was approved in the 407 East Extension EA study. A
           transit station at Whites Road will require EA approval. With the environmental and
           cultural constraints in the vicinity of the proposed Transitway stations at Brock Road,
           Whites Road and also Rossland Road Extension, it may be necessary to advance
           construction of a transit station at York Durham Line (Figure C1.1) in order to serve later
           phases of the Seaton development.

           Further EA studies for both the Whites Road and York Durham Line transit stations
           should be undertaken by Metrolinx and GO Transit in accordance with the EA Act for
           transit projects.

           3.3.2 GO RAIL

           “The Big Move” prepared by Metrolinx identified potential use of the CPR Belleville
           Subdivision and CPR Havelock Subdivision for new passenger GO service passing near
           the Seaton Community to connect with GO stations in Toronto.

           The CPDP proposed a GO station on the south side of Taunton Road west of Brock
           Road. As part of this MESPA, an analysis for the preferred location of the GO station
           was undertaken (refer to Chapter C, Section 7.2).


The Sernas Group Inc., Stonybrook Consulting Inc.   July 2013      Master Environmental Servicing Plan Amendment - Final
SPL Beatty, Bird and Hale Limited, Earthfx Inc.      07161                           Seaton Community, City of Pickering
AMEC Earth & Environmental, R.J. Burnside             C-12
Amos Environment + Planning
           3.3.3 ARTERIAL HIGHER-ORDER TRANSIT

           As part of the CPDP Regional Services Class EA Study, higher order transit on Whites,
           Brock, and Taunton Roads is being examined. The Long Term Transit Study (LTTS) for
           Durham Region recommended Bus Rapid Transit (BRT) service along Whites Road
           (Sideline Road 26) north of Bayly Street, along Brock Road between Bayly Street and
           Highway 7, and along Taunton Road between Whites Road and York Durham Line with
           extensions into Toronto. These BRT services would operate at high frequency and
           ultimately envisions bus-only median lanes. The LTTS also recommended Light Rail
           Transit (LRT) along Taunton Road between Whites Road and Simcoe Street in Oshawa.

3.4        PLANNED FEDERAL PICKERING AIRPORT
           The Federal government has set aside portions of their lands north of Highway 7 and
           west of Brock Road for a potential future airport uses.

           On July 11, 2011, Transport Canada released the findings of the 2010 Pickering Lands
           Needs Assessment Study (http://www.tc.gc.ca/eng/ontario/pickeringstudy.htm).

           According to Transport Canada, “the study was conducted to broaden and update
           previous work on the role and capacity of airports in the Greater Golden Horseshoe area
           in meeting future needs for passenger, cargo and recreational traffic within a 25-year
           horizon. The Government of Canada has noted that the study determined that an
           additional airport will be required in the Greater Golden Horseshoe area in the future and
           that the Pickering Lands would be a prime location for a new airport.” The report
           recommends the Pickering Airport will be required in the Greater Golden Horseshoe
           Area between 2027 and 2037. This MESPA has included planning for transportation
           and other servicing infrastructure for the future airport.

4.0        TRAFFIC DATA
4.1        TRAFFIC COUNTS/VOLUMES
           Traffic data was obtained from the City of Pickering, Region of Durham, Region of York
           and MTO. The recent intersection turning movement counts are as follows in Table

           The traffic volume data listed in the table above are illustrated in Figure C4.1 and the
           data sheets are provided in Appendix C4. The DTY study also included traffic data in
           its analysis.

           The most recent data shows that there has been no growth in the westbound direction
           during the morning peak (commuter traffic) on Highway 7. In contrast, the corresponding
           traffic on 407ETR has seen growth over the last 5 years on an average of almost 10%
           per year.

4.2        TRANSPORTATION TOMORROW SURVEY RESULTS, TRENDS
           AND INTERPRETATION
           The Transportation Tomorrow Survey (TTS) data for Pickering during the morning peak
           period (06:00-09:00) commute was reviewed and the following results were derived
           (refer to Tables C4.2, C4.3 and C4.4).

                                                        TABLE C4.2: MODAL SPLIT

                                                              Auto                                          Transit
                                                    Driver              Passenger                 Local                     GO

                        1991                         63%                   12%                     3%                       8%

The Sernas Group Inc., Stonybrook Consulting Inc.              July 2013            Master Environmental Servicing Plan Amendment - Final
SPL Beatty, Bird and Hale Limited, Earthfx Inc.                 07161                                 Seaton Community, City of Pickering
AMEC Earth & Environmental, R.J. Burnside                        C-14
Amos Environment + Planning
           From the data, trends show that transit modal split remains consistently low at 5%;
           however, trip lengths over time show a decreasing trend. This trend indicates that the
           population in Pickering is finding employment closer to home and not relying on long
           commutes into Toronto. There appears to be a constant (6%) proportion of trips that are
           representative of commuters who continue to use the GO train service into Toronto.

           From the trip distribution data for trip purposes and modes (Table C4.4), it is worth
           noting that all trips from Pickering to the rest of Durham have increased from 48% to
           54% (2001 to 2006) and decreased to Toronto from 42% to 36%, indicating that people
           in Pickering are choosing to make commuter trips locally, within shorter distances.

4.3        FORECASTS
           In the north-south direction, growth is expected along the proposed new links (Rossland
           Road, Whites Road and North Road Extension); however, some of these routes will not
           be continuous due to the proposed Pickering Airport lands, NHS and valley crossings
           and there are few attractions for traffic to and from the north.

           The widening of Highway 7 east of Brock Road and the easterly extension of Highway
           407 in 2017 will significantly alter travel patterns. It is expected that traffic volumes
           along existing east-west routes, such as Taunton Road will initially decrease as traffic
           diverts to Highway 407 East extension and the widened Highway 7. In addition, Brock
           Road traffic between Highway 407 and Rossland Road will reduce initially as traffic to
           and from the east will continue along Highway 407 East and the widened Highway 7.
           The traffic operating parameters at the Brock intersections (at Taunton Road and at
           Rossland Road) will show significant improvement due to these diversions.

           Extrapolating recent TTS trends (Table C4.4), it is relevant to note that significantly more
           than half of trips generated by Seaton will travel within Durham. During the commuter
           peak periods, Seaton residents will travel in the off-peak direction (eastbound in the
           morning and westbound in the evening). The arterial road network will have adequate
           capacity with minimal impacts to operational levels of service to accommodate this
           traffic.

5.0        EVALUATION CRITERIA FOR ROAD ALTERNATIVES
           The CPDP identified preferred alignments and designations for arterial and collector
           roads to serve Seaton and specified the general locations for NHS crossings. The CPDP
           road alignments and designations form the basis for all road projects being addressed in
           this MESPA. As part of fulfilling Phase 1 and 2 of the MEA Class EA, alternatives to the
           CPDP alignments and designations have been investigated and evaluated. It should be
           noted that given the history of and the previous approvals granted to the CPDP, an
           examination of the traditional ‘Do Nothing’ alternative was not applicable and was not
           undertaken.

           This MESPA considered various alternative road alignment and NHS crossing locations
           to those approved in the CPDP. This evaluation was based on the updated information
           found in MESP Phase 1 Report (2008) and completed by the MESPA Study Team since
           then including NHS and cultural heritage information. The goal of the evaluation of


The Sernas Group Inc., Stonybrook Consulting Inc.   July 2013      Master Environmental Servicing Plan Amendment - Final
SPL Beatty, Bird and Hale Limited, Earthfx Inc.      07161                           Seaton Community, City of Pickering
AMEC Earth & Environmental, R.J. Burnside             C-15
Amos Environment + Planning
           alternatives was to minimize potential impacts to natural and cultural resources and to
           implement the Seaton Community as approved in the CPDP.

           Road designations were identified in the Region of Durham Official Plan and the CPDP.
           In this MESPA, alternative road designations were considered in order to reduce
           potential impacts to natural and cultural resources. Road traffic levels and cross-section
           widths have potential to widen corridors through the NHS and increase potential for
           wildlife disruption. The data trends pertaining to the population of Pickering, the location
           and use patterns of the roads by existing community and input from the PICs were
           considered. As a result of the examination of road designations and anticipated traffic
           flows, minor changes to designations and alternative road design standards were
           recommended. The result of these changes will be to minimize right-of-way widths and
           resulting impacts to the NHS. It is important to note that the recommended revisions to
           the road designations will not negatively affect the proposed road network identified in
           the CPDP.

           The CPDP also identified a transit network on Schedule 4 of the CPDP (refer to Figure
           C1.1). Alternatives to the CPDP transit network have been investigated and evaluated
           as part of this MESPA.

           The CPDP mandated the consideration of alternative transportation choices including
           improvements and/or expansion to the transit system. Such improvements would reduce
           reliance on automobiles and thereby reduce environmental impacts. The proposed
           Seaton transit system identified potential improvements that could offer additional trip
           choices for residents to meet this objective. New collector roads were recommended to
           provide bus transit services to development areas. Bus routing systems will ensure that
           the CPDP requirement of 400m walking distance to transit will be implemented.
           Enhanced transit system recommendations include consideration of future GO Transit
           facilities.

           Table C5.1 presents an overview of the evaluation criteria used to assess the Seaton
           arterial and collector road alternatives. Details on the planned Seaton road and transit
           network alternatives are presented in Chapter C, Sections 6.0 and 7.0, respectively.
           Details on the Active Transportation system are provided in Chapter C, Section 8.0.

               TABLE C5.1: SEATON TRANSPORTATION CLASS EA EVALUATION CRITERIA

6.0        PLANNED SEATON ROAD NETWORK
           As outlined in Chapter C, Section 5.0, the CPDP identified alignments and designations
           for arterial and collector roads to serve Seaton including the locations for NHS crossings.
           Alternatives to the CPDP alignments, designations and NHS crossing locations have
           been investigated and evaluated as part of this MESPA to fulfill the requirements of
           Phase 1 and 2 of the MEA Class EA as outlined in the following sections.

6.1        ROAD CROSSINGS OF THE NHS
           As noted in Chapter C, Section 1.1, the CPDP established the need for and location of
           the arterial and collector roads required to implement the Seaton Community. Key
           considerations in the many studies culminating in the approval of the CPDP, related to
           the protection of the NHS lands. This protection was achieved by prohibiting
           development in the NHS lands and by minimizing the number of crossings of the NHS,
           as presented below in an excerpt of the CPDP policies.

           Section 4.6 Servicing, Policy 9, of the CPDP provides the following direction with respect
           to finalizing the locations of the NHS crossings:

                 9. Consider the following principles during the planning and design of
                    transportation and public utilities corridors, recognizing that new crossings
                    of the Natural Heritage System are required to meet the transportation and
                    infrastructure needs of the new community:
                    (a) Avoid road and public utility crossings of the Natural Heritage System,
                        wherever possible;
                    (b) Co-locate unavoidable crossings of the Natural Heritage System with
                        other road or public utility crossings;
                    (c) Where roads and public utilities must cross the Natural Heritage
                        System where there is no existing crossing, locate the corridor within
                        agricultural lands, meadows or successional communities;
                    (d) Locate corridors through significant natural features only where it is
                        demonstrated that no reasonable alternative exists;
                    (e) Where intrusions into significant natural features do occur, make all
                        reasonable attempts to minimize the intrusions and their impacts and
                        to locate such intrusions along peripheral areas of features to avoid
                        fragmentation of the Natural Heritage System;
                    (f) Cross valleys at their narrowest points, wherever possible;
                    (g) Where culverts are used, utilize oversized box culverts placed below
                        grade to provide aquatic and terrestrial linkages;

The Sernas Group Inc., Stonybrook Consulting Inc.               July 2013          Master Environmental Servicing Plan Amendment - Final
SPL Beatty, Bird and Hale Limited, Earthfx Inc.                  07161                               Seaton Community, City of Pickering
AMEC Earth & Environmental, R.J. Burnside                         C-17
Amos Environment + Planning
                       (h) Ensure that the types of crossing structures as determined by the
                           Master Environmental Servicing Plan maximize the preservation of
                           natural habitat and permit natural movement; and
                       (i) Convey surface runoff to adjacent tablelands and not discharge from
                           structures to the valley lands below.”

           In order to comply with the policies of the CPDP, the consideration of alternatives to
           CPDP road alignments in this MESPA was limited to the identification of variations to the
           preferred road alignment identified in the CPDP and there was no consideration of a
           traditional Do Nothing alternative since the Do Nothing alternative would be contrary to
           the policies of the CPDP and could not support the Seaton development.

           In the MESP Phase 1 Report (Existing Conditions, March 2008), the natural heritage
           conditions of thirty-one (31) road crossings were documented. These comprised 16
           crossings of NHS for upgrades/extensions of Regional roads and 15 crossings of NHS
           for upgrades/extensions of existing and additional roads in support of future
           development. The locations of the crossings are illustrated on Figure C6.1, Crossings of
           the NHS. The crossings associated with the Regional roads are identified with a ‘letter’
           (e.g. ‘A’) and those associated with City roads are identified with a ‘number’ (e.g. ‘1’).
           The categorization as ‘regional’ or ‘city’ road reflected the direction in the CPDP.

           As a result of the findings of the MESP Phase 1 Report, 6 additional NHS crossing
           locations were identified for new City roads. These locations also are illustrated on
           Figure C6.1. These additional crossings are labelled as Crossings 16 through 21,
           inclusive. An additional 10 NHS crossings by City roads (Crossings 23 to 32) have been
           identified in the Neighbourhood Plans and are also shown on Figure C6.2. Eight of
           these latter crossings (Crossings 23 to 30) are on local roads in employment lands
           abutting the 407ETR and the alignments are subject to change to comply with
           intersection spacing standards required by MTO and Durham Region. Crossing 31 was
           added to provide secondary (emergency) access between two development areas in
           Neighbourhood 17; and Crossing 32 (comprising a number of small sub-units, 32-i
           through 32-v), also in Neighbourhood 17, was added to comply with Region of Durham
           requirements regarding access to the Taunton and Brock Regional roads. These
           crossings were added, as part of the Neighbourhood Planning process undertaken by
           the City of Pickering and adopted through OPA 22, subsequent to the completion of
           roads investigations by the MESPA. As part of the NFSSR for Neighbourhood 17, these
           two crossings (#31 and #32) will be reviewed and evaluated to the same level of detail
           as occurred for the other City of Pickering roads as per Section C6.2, below, and
           Appendix C6-A.

           The figures documenting the natural heritage conditions for Crossings 16 to 21, using
           the same method and format as the thirty-one (31) crossings included in the MESP
           Phase 1 report, are included in Appendix C6-A.

           The natural heritage conditions of all crossings are summarized in Table 1 of Appendix
           C6-A.

6.2        REVIEW AND EVALUATION OF ALTERNATIVE ROAD
           ALIGNMENTS
           The City of Pickering roads, as identified in the CPDP, were considered in this MESPA.
           As outlined in Chapter C, Section 5.0, alternatives to the CPDP road alignments have
           been investigated to fulfill the requirements of Phase 1 and 2 of the MEA Class EA. As
           a result of the evaluation of alternatives, minor changes to the CPDP road alignments
           have been made to minimize the effects to environmental, social, economic, cultural and
           heritage sensitive areas.

           Tables C6.1 to C6.11 below present the evaluation matrices for each road which were
           utilized to determine the preferred alignments. A brief summary of the evaluation is
           provided for each road followed by the corresponding matrix. Figure C6.3 shows the
           recommended revisions to the Type C Arterial and Collector road alignments compared
           to the CPDP road alignments. It should be noted that potential impacts of the proposed
           crossings of the NHS will be mitigated by the greatest degree possible provided that the
           proposed mitigation measures are adopted and implemented as outlined in Table C11.1
           in Chapter C, Section 11.0.

           Road I: North-South Type C Arterial (Sideline Road 24) (see Table C6.1)

           The segment of this arterial road between Taunton Road and the East-West Collector
           (Road VII) is required from a transportation network connectivity perspective in order to
           provide development traffic and transit service to a high school and community park
           proposed to the north of Road VII and a community node proposed to the south at
           Taunton Road.

           The alignment has been modified from the CPDP to avoid a significant wetland north of
           Taunton Road. The proposed alignment passes to the east side of the feature.

           NHS crossings #11 and #12 as described in the Phase 1 MESP Existing Conditions
           report Appendix E, Figures 5A.27 and 5A.28, and in Table 1 of Appendix C6-A, and
           shown on Figure C6.2, are considered acceptable with the proposed mitigation
           measures adopted as outlined in Table C11.1 in Chapter C, Section 11.0.

            Recommendation: Revise Type C Arterial alignment as shown on Figure C6.3.

Amos Environment + Planning
           Road II: Type C Arterial (Third Concession Road) (between Rossland Road
           Extension and Whites Road) (see Table C6.2)

           The CPDP proposed a Type C arterial generally parallel to and north of Third
           Concession Road between the Rossland Road Extension and Whites Road. There have
           been detailed discussions with the TRCA regarding their concerns on the need for an
           additional crossing of the West Duffins Creek and the potential environmental impacts.

           The MESPA concludes that this road section be deleted for the following reasons.

           •     No demonstrated traffic demand;
           •     No road network connecting to the west, particularly into Toronto;
           •     No transit benefit or need;
           •     Requires additional crossing of West Duffins Creek which has significant adverse
                 environmental impacts;
           •     Road is aligned through NHS and therefore there will be no development requiring
                 access or transit service; and,
           •     Access is available and adequate for the properties fronting onto existing Third
                 Concession Road.

           Recommendation: For reasons presented in Table C6.2, this East-West Arterial is being
           removed from further consideration.

           Road II continues to be listed in the consideration of alternative arterial and collector
           roads because it was identified as part of the arterial and collector road network in the
           CPDP. Figure C6.3 shows the original CPDP road network as well as the arterial and
           collector roads proposed as a result of the MESPA evaluation. Road II has remained
           part of the overall evaluation of the Seaton arterial and collector roads in order to comply
           with the MESP Terms of Reference, to confirm the reasons for its removal, and to
           provide complete documentation.

           Road III: North Road Type C Arterial (see Table C6.3)

           To accommodate the intersection of this road (which has an overpass at 407ETR) with
           Road IV, minor alignment modifications are required.

           At the proposed intersection of the existing North Road and Road IV, a roundabout is
           proposed to define an entry into the Hamlet of Whitevale and deter traffic infiltration.
           Combined with the realignment with Road IV, it provides more efficient development as
           well as improved transit coverage.

           NHS Crossing 10 as described in Phase 1 MESP Existing Conditions report Appendix E,
           Figure 5A.26, and in Table 1 of Appendix C6-A, and shown on Figure C6.1, is
           considered acceptable with the proposed mitigation measures.

           Recommendation: Revise Type C Arterial alignment as shown on Figure C6.3.

           Road IV: East-West Special Type C Arterial (between North Road and Rossland
           Road Extension (see Tables C6.4 and C6.5)

           This segment of the CPDP Arterial remains designated as a Type C Arterial from North
           Road to Rossland Road Extension. This road is Special Type C Arterial to provide
           reduced right-of-way width; provide parking bays where appropriate; provide flexible
           frontage and access controls; provide intersection spacing options and encourage on-
           street and pedestrian activity. Minor modifications to the alignment are proposed to
           accommodate the intersections with North Road and with Road IX - North-South
           Collector (Sideline Road 28).

           NHS crossings #2 to #4 and #9 as described in Phase 1 MESP Existing Conditions
           report Appendix E Figures 5A.18, 5A.19, 5A.20, and 5A.25, and in Table 1 of Appendix
           C6-A, and shown on Figure C6.2, are considered acceptable with the proposed
           mitigation measures.

           Recommendation: Adopt Special Type C designation and revise alignment as shown on
           Figure C6.3.

           Road V: Collector Road in Northeast Quadrant of Whitevale Road and Rossland
           Road Extension (CPDP East-West Type C Arterial) (see Tables C6.4 and C6.5)

           The proposed alignment generally follows the CPDP; however, the road classification is
           proposed to be down-graded to a collector to create options for access; intersection
           spacing and a 90o bend to better accommodate the residential development. Road
           network continuity is not required and transit routes and service levels are not affected.

           NHS crossing #1 as described in Phase 1 MESP Existing Conditions report Appendix E,
           Figure 5A.17, and in Table 1 of Appendix C6-A, and shown on Figure C6.2, is
           considered acceptable with the proposed mitigation.

           Recommendation: Revise Type C Arterial to a Collector designation and adopt the
           alignment as shown on Figure C6.3.

SPL Beatty, Bird and Hale Limited, Earthfx Inc.                                        07161                                                      Seaton Community, City of Pickering
AMEC Earth & Environmental, R.J. Burnside                                               C-27
Amos Environment + Planning
           Road VI: Employment Collector (see Table C6.6)

           This collector road alignment was improved by minimizing the potential for
           environmental (NHS, wetland and forest) and cultural impacts while improving
           intersection spacing at the approaches to the proposed 407ETR interchange ramps.
           The single-loaded development frontage was reduced and the overall road length was
           reduced to 3.75 km with anticipated lower construction costs. The alignment of the
           collector west of Whites Road was determined partially by location of the Whites Road
           Transitway station on lands by MTO and the existing environmental area, as well as the
           limits of the NHS. The alignment west of the Rossland Road Extension was selected
           due to the discovery of a culturally significant archaeological site and environmentally
           sensitive features, including woodlands and wetlands.

           The intersection of Road VI with North Road also was relocated north of the CPDP
           location for two reasons: to bring the alignment out of and away from the NHS and
           provide potential for double-loaded development lots. The existing local road on the
           west side of North Road can be realigned opposite the collector.

           NHS crossings #16 to #21 as described in Appendix C6-A (Figures 1 to 5 and Table 1)
           and shown on Figure C6.2, are considered acceptable with the proposed mitigation
           measures.

           Recommendation: Revise collector alignment as shown on Figure C6.3.

           Road X: Old Brock Collector (see Table C6.10)

           This is a new collector that was not originally identified in the CPDP. This collector
           would be built on a section of the existing Brock Road which will be taken out of use
           when the realigned Brock Road is constructed. The new collector (Old Brock Collector)
           would have two intersections to the realigned Brock Road to comply with the CPDP
           requirements for transit service coverage to the employment lands abutting the 407ETR.
           The new collector allows for a looping of transit vehicles and thus avoids dead heading
           transit routes while enhancing access for emergency vehicles.

           There are no NHS crossings identified.

           Recommendation: Adopt the new collector alignment as shown on Figure C6.3.

           Road XI: Mulberry Lane Collector (see Table C6.11)

           This is a new collector that was not originally identified in the CPDP. This collector is
           required to provide transit service to the residential development area in the vicinity of
           Mulberry Lane which is located west of Brock Road and south of existing Whitevale
           Road. The alignment requires widening of the Mulberry Lane road allowance along the
           eastern boundary and cannot be widened to the west due to cultural heritage
           constraints. A portion of Mulberry Lane will have a pavement width of 12m to satisfy
           emergency access.

           An additional potential future connection to Whitevale Road was added as part of the
           Neighbourhood Planning process undertaken by the City of Pickering and adopted
           through OPA 22. It crosses the NHS, identified as crossing #22 on Figure C6.2 and
           described in Appendix C6-A (Figure 6 and Table 1). This NHS crossing is considered
           acceptable with the proposed mitigation measures.

           Recommendation: Adopt the new collector alignments as shown on Figure C6.3.

AMEC Earth & Environmental, R.J. Burnside                                                    C-39
Amos Environment + Planning
           6.2.1 SPECIES AT RISK

           Species at Risk which have been identified in the Seaton Study Area and are regulated
           by the Ontario Endangered Species Act and the federal Species at Risk Act, include:
           Redside Dace, Bobolink, Least Bittern and Butternut. As well Atlantic Salmon, although
           classified as ‘extinct’ by COSSARO, MNR is implementing an Atlantic Salmon long-term
           restoration program.

           Findings of this investigation and the implications of those findings are discussed more
           fully in Chapter E and summarized here:

           •     Redside Dace and Bobolink will be addressed through Overall Benefit Permits per
                 Section 17 of the Endangered Species Act and/or provisions of Ontario Regulation
                 293/11 as applicable;
           •     Atlantic Salmon will be addressed by Redside Dace Permits where required where
                 in-water work is required in a Redside Dace occupied or recovery reach of
                 Ganatsekiagon Creek, but will require its own permit for West Duffins Creek (and is
                 not an issue for other creeks);
           •     The known location of Least Bittern has no implications to development in Seaton;
                 and,
           •     For the road alignments that were shown in the CPDP, a 100m swath centred on all
                 of the road alignment locations was inventoried and those alignments were
                 determined to be free of Butternut trees.

           Therefore, for all alignments that were not within 100m of the centre-line of the CPDP
           alignments, additional inventory work will be required to identify whether Butternut trees
           are located where they could be harmed or destroyed. If the species is present, it will be
           addressed as outlined in Table C6.13 and further discussed in Chapter E.

           In the future, either at the time of the preparation of the Phases 3 and 4 MEA Class EA
           studies for these City roads and for other roads not subject to Phases 3 and 4 of the
           Class EA process, at final design, ‘Species Lists’ under the provincial Endangered
           Species Act and the federal Species at Risk Act will be reviewed to determine if study
           updates are required.

           The review and evaluation of alignment modifications as presented above in Chapter C,
           Section 6.2 has resulted in the following recommendations with regard to Endangered
           Species.

           1. Site specific mitigation will be incorporated into the design of NHS crossings, as
              discussed in Chapter C Sections 6.4.2 and 11.0 below. No terrestrial compensation
              is envisaged where these road crossings of the NHS were established by the CPDP;
              however, if additional road crossings are added, or if the road location is moved to a
              location where greater impacts to the NHS would occur, then compensation would
              be required. The compensation would be as discussed in Chapter C Section 11.0,
              Table C11.1, and comprises naturalization of suitable areas of NHS lands to
              appropriate habitat. Moreover, the implications of additional crossings of Redside
              Dace habitat and the Overall Benefit Plan or Mitigation Plan for this species (see
              Chapter E) will have to be addressed.



The Sernas Group Inc., Stonybrook Consulting Inc.   July 2013     Master Environmental Servicing Plan Amendment - Final
SPL Beatty, Bird and Hale Limited, Earthfx Inc.      07161                          Seaton Community, City of Pickering
AMEC Earth & Environmental, R.J. Burnside             C-40
Amos Environment + Planning
           2. For all stream crossings, where there is potential for harmful alteration, disruption or
              destruction or disturbance (HADD) at stream crossings, under the Federal Fisheries
              Act, a framework for fisheries compensation has been provided in Chapter F, and
              may be in addition to any requirements associated with Redside Dace Overall
              Benefit Plan or Mitigation Plan for those tributaries for which the Overall Benefit Plan
              is applicable.

6.3        REVIEW AND EVALUATION OF ALTERNATIVE ROAD
           DESIGNATIONS
           As outlined in Chapter C, Section 5.0, alternatives to the CPDP road designations have
           been investigated and evaluated to fulfill the requirements of Phase 1 and 2 of the MEA
           Class EA. As a result of the evaluation of alternatives, minor changes to the CPDP road
           designations have been made. Table C6.12 summarizes the results of the CPDP road
           designation evaluations.

             Number
              from                                                                                                                                                        MESPA
                                            City Road                 CPDP                                 MESPA Evaluation
