The Sernas Group Inc., Stonybrook Consulting Inc.                                       July 2013                                     Master Environmental Servicing Plan Amendment - Final
SPL Beatty, Bird and Hale Limited, Earthfx Inc.                                          07161                                                          Seaton Community, City of Pickering
AMEC Earth & Environmental, R.J. Burnside                                                 C-42
Amos Environment + Planning
6.4        CITY ROAD AND CROSSING DESIGN STANDARDS
           Based on the review of CPDP road alignments and designations, the MESPA
           recommends that the following design standards and considerations be applied for roads
           and crossings of the NHS.

           6.4.1 ROAD DESIGN STANDARDS

           6.4.1.1          Type C Arterial

           The right-of-way shall be kept to a minimum and shall not exceed a maximum of 30m,
           and more typically have a right-of-way of 24m (as stated in Section 11.29 of the OP
           Conformity document and agreed to by the SLG). The exception is at the approaches to
           major intersections where medians and/or additional lanes are required. Similarly, the
           pavement width typically shall be 15m (four basic lanes during peak periods; two lanes
           per direction) (see Figure in Appendix C6-B); however, can be wider to accommodate
           turning lanes, bike lanes, parking, and bus lay-bys.

           In accordance with CPDP policies, bike paths and/or bike lanes will be provided, and
           where possible, with 3m wide multi-use paths within the boulevard on each side.

           6.4.1.2          Special Type C Arterial

           For the Special Type C Arterial (Road IV), the City will be considering modified
           standards for right-of-way width including two travel lanes with left turn lanes at
           intersections, on-road bicycle lanes on each side, reduced intersection spacing,
           provision for parking bays where appropriate and flexible frontage and access controls.

           6.4.1.3          Collector

           The right-of-way shall be kept to a minimum and shall not exceed a maximum of 23m,
           and more typically have a right-of-way of 20m, except at the approaches to major
           intersections where medians and/or additional lanes are required. The Collector roads
           in residential areas will consist of two travelled lanes with on-road bike lanes on both
           sides and parking lay-bys along one side. Parking will not be permitted along Collectors
           in employment areas to promote an efficient flow of transit and truck movements,
           however on-road bike lanes or shared on-road bike facilities on both sides may be
           provided for linkage.

           6.4.1.4          General Standards

           As part of the Environmental Servicing Plan (ESP) for Duffin Heights, the City of
           Pickering approved reduced right-of-way widths and these reductions have been
           accepted for use by the Region of Durham and local utility providers. This MESPA
           recommends that these standards be used within Seaton.

           Roads crossing the NHS will have a rural cross-section, wherever possible; that is no
           curbs and gutters. “It is desirable to coordinate the NHS crossings design with the


The Sernas Group Inc., Stonybrook Consulting Inc.     July 2013   Master Environmental Servicing Plan Amendment - Final
SPL Beatty, Bird and Hale Limited, Earthfx Inc.        07161                        Seaton Community, City of Pickering
AMEC Earth & Environmental, R.J. Burnside               C-43
Amos Environment + Planning
           Regional arterials and there needs to be consultation between the City and the CPDP
           Regional Services Class EA Study team to reach a consensus on the design.”

           These cross-sections are provided in Appendix C6-B and have been extracted from the
           City of Pickering report “Seaton Sustainable Place-Making Guidelines, July 2011 (draft)”.

           6.4.2 NHS CROSSING DESIGN CONSIDERATIONS

           The NHS will be crossed by several roadways as established by the CPDP and as
           shown on Figures C6.1 and C6.2. The selection of these crossing areas, based on the
           CPDP planned locations for the roads and by additional evaluation in this MESPA, has
           taken into account the characteristics of the NHS including terrestrial features, aquatic
           features, or both. To meet the goal of minimizing potential for environmental impacts of
           the proposed road crossings, the MESP Study Team recommends road alignments that
           avoid wetlands and woodlands. Where the crossing is a necessity, then crossing widths
           have been minimized.

           For all City roads, road design will be outlined in the Neighbourhood Plan and
           Neighbourhood Functional Servicing and Stormwater Reports (NFSSRs). Prior to the
           construction of any roads or buildings, detailed design subject to review and approvals
           by the City of Pickering, TRCA, MNR and other relevant agencies must be approved.

           For the three City roads subject to Schedule ‘C’ of the MEA Class EA process, the
           design requirements for each watercourse or terrestrial natural heritage feature crossing
           will be considered further on a site specific basis during the future Environmental Study
           Reports to satisfy Phases 3 and 4 of the MEA Class EA. The design and opening size
           for all NHS crossings, where applicable, must address a number of basic parameters,
           including fluvial geomorphology, hydraulics, and wildlife passage requirements.

           For each segment of a City road which is proposed to cross through or intrude into the
           NHS, a Roads Checklist Form was prepared (see Appendix C6-C). The Form indicates
           which criteria or mitigation measure should be followed and when (i.e. large mammal
           crossing design at the NFSSR stage). It also provides direction to site specific
           assessments outlining any special conditions or design considerations for that NHS road
           segment. This Roads Checklist Form is to be annotated with the assessment results by
           the NFSSRs, providing a summary of the design parameters for each road segment
           through the NHS.

           As shown below, and on the Roads Checklist Forms, there are numerous criteria that
           must be considered, but not all criteria would be applicable for all road segments. In
           terrestrial locations, the use of NHS crossings by wildlife will affect the design. In
           channel crossing locations, the overriding criterion dictating the size of the opening will
           be the one that results in the largest opening size.

           Twenty-seven (27) Roads Checklist Forms have been prepared, applicable to crossings
           1, 2, 3, 4, 9, 11, 12, 13, 14, 15a, 15b, 16, 17, 18, 19, 20, 21, 22, 23, 25, 26, 27, 28, 29,
           30, 31 and 32 (Appendix C6-C). The location and extent of each crossing is shown on
           Figure C6.2. There are no Roads Checklist Forms for crossings 5, 6, 7, 8, 10 as these
           are existing roads (Whitevale Road and North Road) that are not being modified at this
           time, and are not subject to assessment at the NFSSR stage. However, these crossings

The Sernas Group Inc., Stonybrook Consulting Inc.   July 2013      Master Environmental Servicing Plan Amendment - Final
SPL Beatty, Bird and Hale Limited, Earthfx Inc.      07161                           Seaton Community, City of Pickering
AMEC Earth & Environmental, R.J. Burnside             C-44
Amos Environment + Planning
           continue to be shown on Figure C6.1 and in Table 1 of Appendix C6-A as
           modifications to these roads may occur in the future, and existing conditions information
           has been acquired through this MESP process. Further, there is no crossing #24, and
           thus no checklist for this crossing. All other crossings through the NHS (i.e. the ‘lettered’
           crossings, A, B, C... etc.), are Regional Roads, the design of which is being undertaken
           through the CPDP Regional Services Class EA Study.

           The NFSSRs will provide a preliminary plan and profile for each of the above noted
           roads segments through the NHS.

           The design criteria to be applied to City roads through the NHS are detailed in Table
           C6.13, below.

         TABLE C6.13: DESIGN CONSIDERATIONS FOR CITY ROADS THROUGH SEATON NHS

         Criterion                                            Assessment Requirements
1. Hydraulics                      •     Crossings are to be sized to convey the applicable storm as per Pickering
                                         Stormwater Management Guidelines, which is the greater of the 50 year
                                         flood flow, or the flood flow specified by Ontario Ministry of Transportation
                                         Design Flood Criteria Directive B-100.
                                   •     Crossings are to be sized in accordance with TRCA floodplain management
                                         criteria for water crossings.
                                   •     The crossings are to be sized, based on the flow regimes predicted for the
                                         post-development conditions, paying special attention to intermittent
                                         channels/swales that may exhibit more persistent flow conditions post-
                                         development.
                                   •     The proposed crossings should be assessed to ensure MNR requirements
                                         for safe egress are achieved (i.e. ensure road profiles are such that if a
                                         structure is overtopped during a Regional Storm event, then the depth of
                                         flooding will not impede emergency vehicles).
2. Fluvial                         •     The following criteria are recommended for crossing placement and design.
   Geomorphology                         The crossing location should:
                                           o be stable, relatively straight reach of channel, where possible;
                                           o within an envelope outside the potential future migration of upstream
                                                meanders (a 100-year planning horizon);
                                           o cross the stream perpendicular to the channel, whenever possible.
                                   •     The crossing opening should address potential channel migration, with the
                                         aim to minimizing or avoiding the requirements for armouring or impacting
                                         channel migration or adjustment (100-year planning horizon), considering
                                         post-development conditions, especially for intermittent channels/swales
                                         where the flow regime may change under post-development conditions.
                                         The minimum structural requirement from a geomorphic perspective is to
                                         ensure that abutments on any watercourse crossing are located outside the
                                         100 year erosion limit. Crossings will avoid, to the best extent possible,
                                         watercourses that have fine sediment banks and are vegetation controlled.
                                         Where it is not possible to avoid fine sediment banks and vegetation
                                         control, formalizing the channel with appropriate bed and/or bank
                                         treatments may be required to avoid splaying/braiding under low flow
                                         conditions.
                                   •     The crossing opening should not:
                                         o impact channel velocity for frequent storm events;
                                         o Impact the local existing meander pattern; and

The Sernas Group Inc., Stonybrook Consulting Inc.             July 2013          Master Environmental Servicing Plan Amendment - Final
SPL Beatty, Bird and Hale Limited, Earthfx Inc.                07161                               Seaton Community, City of Pickering
AMEC Earth & Environmental, R.J. Burnside                       C-45
Amos Environment + Planning
         Criterion                                             Assessment Requirements
                                         o impact sediment transport processes for frequent storm events.
                                   •     Other hazards that should be addressed include:
                                         o bedload conveyance through the crossing;
                                         o potential change in channel alignment and bank erosion in adjoining
                                              reaches; and
                                         o ice jams and woody debris, where applicable.
3. Stormwater                      •     Quality, erosion and quantity controls must be provided for road drainage,
   Management                            through the implementation of best management practices and low impact
   Requirements                          development measures.
                                   •     Storm drainage from urban cross-section roads should be directed to
                                         stormwater management facilities unless grades are prohibitive. Where
                                         this is the case, alternative BMP/LIDs will be considered to address water
                                         management requirements.
4. Fisheries                       •     The general intent is to leave existing bed of channels untouched, thus
                                         minimizing the extent of a HADD.
                                   •     Open bottom structures are required for all channel crossings.
                                   •     Where a structure is required to direct accumulated flow from a non-
                                         channelized area (i.e. no channel present), the structure should be
                                         designed to accommodate the function of the replicated flow.
                                   •     If a HADD is identified, review the Overall Fisheries Compensation Plan,
                                         and identify the Opportunities for Compensation indicated in the Plan.
                                         Provide direction re: implementation.
5. Geotechnical and                •     The soil conditions and slope stability (where applicable) at a proposed
   Hydrogeology                          crossing must be assessed to identify construction constraints.
                                   •     The local groundwater conditions should be identified (i.e. depth to water
                                         table, potential for groundwater/surface water interaction (discharge), and
                                         need for construction dewatering) at the crossing location to maintain or
                                         enhance existing discharge function.
                                   •     Where dewatering will be necessary, the pumping requirements and
                                         potential impacts should be identified and the appropriate monitoring and
                                         mitigation plans should be prepared.
6. Wildlife Passage                •     Wildlife passage needs to be addressed for every location where a road
                                         segment will cross through the NHS. The characteristics of the NHS in
                                         each location will dictate the requirements related to wildlife passage. The
                                         characteristics may vary from: a narrow watercourse crossing, with adjacent
                                         narrow bands of currently agriculture; a watercourse crossing with a well-
                                         defined, diversely vegetated valley, with or without adjacent terrestrial NHS
                                         that may or may not currently be well vegetated; and, areas where no
                                         watercourse is present and the vegetation may vary from current agriculture
                                         to structurally diverse natural communities.
                                   •     For a successful crossing, the design must consider: the existing and future
                                         habitat conditions; the wildlife functional groups in the vicinity and wildlife
                                         accessibility; and, human activity that will occur in the future (in addition to
                                         the road, i.e. trails, sidewalks). Design components must include:
                                         appropriate structure design (shape, size, light, moisture); appropriate road
                                         design elements (curbs, barriers, ditches); and, traffic control measures
                                         (signage, speed limit).
                                   •     Wildlife functional groups comprise: large mammals (e.g. deer); medium
                                         mammals (e.g. raccoon); small mammals; amphibians and riparian reptiles;
                                         and, upland reptiles (some snakes). Additionally, there are fish; these are
                                         addressed under #4, above. Many crossings will function for a number of
                                         wildlife groups and the points, below, reflect this.

The Sernas Group Inc., Stonybrook Consulting Inc.              July 2013           Master Environmental Servicing Plan Amendment - Final
SPL Beatty, Bird and Hale Limited, Earthfx Inc.                 07161                                Seaton Community, City of Pickering
AMEC Earth & Environmental, R.J. Burnside                        C-46
Amos Environment + Planning
         Criterion                                            Assessment Requirements
                                   •     Some researchers and Agencies recommend the use of the ‘Openness
                                         Index’ (width of opening x height of opening [clearance])/length of opening)
                                         for openings (culverts, bridges, underpasses) planned for wildlife use. This
                                         tool can be used to determine if the opening is generally suitable for the
                                         proposed wildlife groups:
                                         o For large mammals - have an openness index of at least 0.75 but
                                              preferably 0.9;
                                         o For medium mammals – have an openness index of at least 0.4;
                                         o For small mammals, amphibians and riparian reptiles, the literature
                                              suggests quite a large range but indicate that smaller openness indices
                                              are more appealing to these groups, as long as a dry shoulder is
                                              maintained. It is suggested that the openness index could range from a
                                              low of 0.08 to 0.4;
                                         o For upland reptiles, the literature indicates that the use of the Openness
                                              Index is not useful.
                                         o The appropriateness of the openness index should be considered in the
                                              context of the site specific conditions in any given location and the
                                              species anticipated to inhabit the NHS in that location, at the NFSSR or
                                              detailed design phases, as applicable.

                                    Channel Crossing Requirements:
                                    • Where aquatic habitat exists, the crossing structures should be open
                                       bottom and accommodate the existing substrate.
                                    • Where large top-of-bank to top-of-bank structures will be required to span
                                       a deep valley, it may provide suitable height and width for all wildlife
                                       groups.
                                    • The requirements for target (i.e. those in the area that will utilize the
                                       crossing) wildlife groups are outlined below.
                                       o Large sized and medium sized mammals require an open field of view
                                          (i.e. can see to the other side of the opening), and preferably structures
                                          that are taller in height, shorter in length, with larger cross-sectional
                                          areas and openness indices. Smaller sized mammals will use these
                                          openings as well.
                                       o Larger sized mammals require openings with a minimum of 3m height.
                                       o Medium sized mammals require openings with 1-1.2m height.
                                       o Small sized mammals, amphibians, and riparian reptiles require
                                          openings with 0.3-0.5m height.
                                       o All non-aquatic wildlife groups require a continuous terrestrial bench
                                          beside the flow channel. Although some small mammals and herptiles
                                          have been known to utilize benches of as small as 0.4m, in most
                                          situations a minimum width of ~3-4m, would be required on both sides
                                          of channel bank where the connectivity is required to accommodate
                                          medium and large sized mammals. The target species and the specific
                                          bench size will be determined at the NFSSR or detailed design phases,
                                          as applicable.
                                   •   To further enhance the potential for wildlife use of the crossing structures,
                                       any valley design and naturalization plans should meet the following
                                       requirements:
                                       o The road embankments (from both sides of the road to the valley
                                           system) should not have overly steep grades. Slope conditions should
                                           encourage funnelling of wildlife but should not be so steep that wildlife
                                           could not readily leave adjacent level areas to access the opening.
                                       o The embankments on both sides of the road should be planted with

The Sernas Group Inc., Stonybrook Consulting Inc.             July 2013          Master Environmental Servicing Plan Amendment - Final
SPL Beatty, Bird and Hale Limited, Earthfx Inc.                07161                               Seaton Community, City of Pickering
AMEC Earth & Environmental, R.J. Burnside                       C-47
Amos Environment + Planning
         Criterion                                             Assessment Requirements
                                               structurally diverse native indigenous species that would provide cover
                                               in the vicinity of the road but that would not impede sight of the
                                               opening.
                                   •     To enhance the visibility of the opening for wildlife, to encourage funnelling
                                         of wildlife to the opening, and to discourage them from exiting the opening
                                         to the road surface, a hard surface apron around the entrance, and a lip
                                         around the top of the opening are recommended.
                                   •     The route to the opening (on both sides of the road) should be planted with
                                         indigenous species that provide cover to the fauna.

                                   Terrestrial Crossing Requirements:
                                   • Adjacent to channel crossings and in locations where no channel is present
                                       where a road segment crosses through the NHS, wildlife connectivity also
                                       should be addressed.
                                   • For Amphibians/Reptiles:
                                       o Where a channel crossing is not required but where amphibian/riparian
                                           reptile habitat exists in close proximity to both sides of a road (±∼100m)
                                           or there is evidence that amphibians are broadcasting across the
                                           terrain, an underpass may be required.
                                       o Where broadcast movement is to be supported, the crossings should
                                           be placed at a high frequency (e.g. ~50m).
                                       o Crossing structures for this wildlife group can have small openings
                                           although it is difficult to ensure that the microclimate in the structure is
                                           not significantly different from their surroundings, which is easier to
                                           accomplish with larger openings. The crossing structure should have a
                                           minimum diameter of ~0.3-0.5m, but this will depend on the road width
                                           and should result in the appropriate openness index. Concrete or PVC
                                           materials are preferred to help maintain ambient temperatures. The
                                           base material for the crossings should be natural materials, preferably
                                           soil and stone from the surrounding area.
                                       o Crossing structures for amphibians should have grated openings (to
                                           barrier predatory small mammals from entering), flush with the road to
                                           allow for greater air and moisture flow and improved ambient light, thus
                                           enhancing the potential to maintain suitable microclimatic conditions.
                                           The crossing structure must provide non-flooded but moist passage.
                                       o There has been good success where the barrier/guiding feature to the
                                           crossing structure entrance includes a +15 cm horizontal lip along its
                                           top (herptiles and small mammals are not able to clamber over this
                                           barrier (‘gravity takes over’) to access the road). The guiding feature
                                           may be concrete slab or block that faces (covers) the verge, forming an
                                           apron around the entrance to the underpass – this would be topped
                                           with the lip or rim. This design is preferred, as it does not create a
                                           barrier for fauna crossing at grade, and the regular maintenance
                                           requirements would be less than for a drift fence.
                                       o The vegetation cover at the crossing structure entrance should be low
                                           stature (forbs, graminoids), to prevent the wildlife climbing up the
                                           vegetation. Low stature vegetation (forbs, graminoids, small shrubs)
                                           cover in the vicinity and other naturally occurring habitat, such as tree
                                           stumps, hollow logs, or rocks, is beneficial to provide cover from
                                           predators and encourage passage through a structure.
                                   • For Mammals:
                                       o It is not required to create terrestrial underpass crossings for large


The Sernas Group Inc., Stonybrook Consulting Inc.             July 2013           Master Environmental Servicing Plan Amendment - Final
SPL Beatty, Bird and Hale Limited, Earthfx Inc.                07161                                Seaton Community, City of Pickering
AMEC Earth & Environmental, R.J. Burnside                       C-48
Amos Environment + Planning
         Criterion                                             Assessment Requirements
                                             sized mammals.
                                         o   In some locations where road designs and grades can accommodate it,
                                             underpass crossings for medium mammals could be considered.
                                             These mammals (e.g. raccoon, skunk, fox, etc.) are not frequent users
                                             of underpasses in urban settings (typically they broadcast their
                                             movements through the community), and therefore should only be
                                             considered for locations where there is a reasonable road segment
                                             length through the NHS. If an underpass is proposed, its design should
                                             address the openness index, opening height and line of sight, as
                                             discussed above, under ‘Channel Crossings’.
                                         o Where an underpass is not proposed, the road should be kept to as
                                             close to at-grade with the surrounding lands (i.e. there should not be
                                             any steep grades immediately beside the road rights-of-way).
                                         o On both sides of the roads, vegetation that provides cover should be
                                             established, while maintaining a clear line-of-sight for drivers, along the
                                             shoulders of the road (i.e. there should be a strip of low stature
                                             vegetation or shoulder beside the travel surface).
                                         o Appropriate signage should be placed on the road (warnings related to
                                             wildlife crossing, speed limit reduction, no passing).
                                         o No physical barrier to at-grade crossings should be established (e.g. no
                                             continuous fencing that extends to the ground surface). Guard rails/
                                             guide rails/posts have not been found to create a barrier to movement.
                                         o Reflectors/reflecting material on guard rails/guide rails/posts/road
                                             edges, etc. may enhance the ability of the wildlife to pick up on the
                                             vehicles. This is more beneficial than increased street lighting, which
                                             may deter some animals from using the crossing location.
                                   •     Alternative road design standards may minimize implications to wildlife
                                         movement. The travelled surface of the road should be kept to the
                                         minimum permitted and the road segments should be relatively straight.
                                         Rural road cross-sections may be suitable in locations where steep grade
                                         changes do not exist across the road, where roadside swales can be
                                         accommodated without creating substantial swaths within the NHS; and,
                                         where length allows. The locations for light poles should be considered,
                                         based on the wildlife expected to utilize the crossing.
7. Vegetation                      •     Edge management will be required where existing edges have to be
   Management                            removed and where the interior of a woodland is exposed. Cut woody
                                         material could be left in situ to provide habitat and cover, unless diseased.
                                         Alternatively, cut material could be chipped and used on site as ground
                                         mulch. In general, other than where concerns of public safety exist, snags
                                         and deadfalls should be left in place. There should not be any significant
                                         landscaping or manicuring of areas that are to be left to function naturally.
                                   •     Restoration measures should be implemented wherever and whenever
                                         communities are disturbed/removed to accommodate road construction.
                                         The restored vegetation community should reflect the cover that was
                                         present (e.g. wetland or upland). Exceptions exist where (1) the cover is
                                         agriculture in which case full restoration should occur; and (2) herbaceous
                                         cover is appropriate to establish clear lines-of-sight for wildlife-vehicle
                                         safety.
                                   •     Where the location of the road has been altered from that shown in the
                                         CPDP and impacts to the NHS are greater (i.e. road moved from across
                                         agricultural cover to across a natural community) or where additional road
                                         crossings of the NHS are proposed, compensation is required for any


The Sernas Group Inc., Stonybrook Consulting Inc.              July 2013          Master Environmental Servicing Plan Amendment - Final
SPL Beatty, Bird and Hale Limited, Earthfx Inc.                 07161                               Seaton Community, City of Pickering
AMEC Earth & Environmental, R.J. Burnside                        C-49
Amos Environment + Planning
         Criterion                                            Assessment Requirements
                                         natural community that would be removed. The compensation should
                                         ensure that there is a net gain to natural cover within the NHS. The
                                         compensation should occur within the areas of the NHS that currently
                                         support agricultural uses, and endeavour to replace the lost natural heritage
                                         features (e.g. wetland with wetland, woodland with woodland).
                                         In locations where a road may traverse the surface catchment of a natural
                                         heritage feature, especially wetlands, road design must ensure
                                         maintenance of drainage to the feature per a water balance calculation.
8. Species at Risk                 •     Regarding Butternut trees, confirm that no Butternut trees are present on or
                                         in vicinity of alignment.
                                   •     If present, undertake a Butternut Health Assessment after which, and
                                         depending upon the health and number of specimens present, either:
                                         o Modify alignment, or
                                         o Apply for permit for removal, following the requirements of Section 5 of
                                              Ontario Regulation 242/08 for Butternut (under the Endangered
                                              Species Act [ESA]; as to be revised in 2011).
                                   •     Regarding Redside Dace, confirm category of any channels in
                                         subcatchment (i.e. occupied, recovery or indirect) and meet requirements of
                                         Overall Benefit Plan for Redside Dace (described in Chapter E of this
                                         MESPA).
                                   •     Other ESA species (as of April 2011) have been addressed in the MESPA,
                                         Chapter E, and therefore do not need to be addressed in the NFSSRs.
                                   •     In the future (i.e. beyond the summer of 2011), as development plans are
                                         implemented, the ESA should be revisited to determine whether additional
                                         species present in the plan area have been added to the ‘endangered’ or
                                         ‘threatened’ category, and would need to be addressed.
9. Road Design                     •     Design standards for NHS crossings should be coordinated with the City
                                         and the Region for consistent application.
                                   •     Each NHS crossing should be assessed to determine whether a rural
                                         cross-section is feasible or whether the road should continue as an urban
                                         (or semi-urban with rolled curb and roadside ditches) cross-section through
                                         the NHS. This should be based on such factors as: length, grade, design
                                         speed, and abutting land cover.
                                   •     Where NHS crossing has suitable characteristics for the road to
                                         accommodate the transition from urban to rural cross-section, the following
                                         shall be considered:
                                         o Transition curb treatment (start and end of the urban section)
                                         o Accommodate roadway drainage
                                         o Provide for the continuation of sidewalk and/or integrate with trail
                                         o Provide for the continuation of bike lane
                                         o Provide for the continuation of street lighting although the type of
                                              lighting should be sensitive to the NHS (i.e. full cut off)
                                         o Provide appropriate signage for transition into and out NHS
                                         o Provide for guiderail, if necessary
                                         o Provide safety features for all modes such as vehicles, pedestrian,
                                              cyclists, etc.
                                         o Provide access to utilities
10. Natural Heritage               •     Review plan for Natural Heritage System Trails and Trails/bike routes to

7.0        SEATON TRANSIT NETWORK

7.1        DURHAM TRANSIT (POTENTIAL ROUTES/COVERAGE)
           For bus routings in Seaton, a number of alternative routing plans were developed and
           assessed in order to ensure that the requirement for 400m walking distance for transit
           access is achieved. This requirement has made it necessary for the addition of two new
           collector roads to the CPDP to provide adequate coverage (400m walking distance). As
           a consequence, emergency access has been improved. The Plan defines major transit
           corridors as “corridors that have the potential to develop into higher order service in
           exclusive rights-of-way, and facilitate inter-regional and local travel”. Accordingly, the
           following corridors are identified as Major transit corridors:

           •     Highway 407 Transitway;
           •     Brock Road,
           •     Taunton Road;
           •     Whites Road/Sideline Road 26 and
           •     Highway 7.

           According to the CPDP, these corridors will:

           •     Provide a direct connection to York and Peel Regions along Highway 407, as well as
                 to major employment and institutional uses near the highway;
           •     Provide a direct connection to the Pickering GO Rail Station on the Lakeshore East
                 GO Rail line along Brock Road, as well as the Highway 2 transit corridor and the
                 future Seaton GO Station;
           •     Connect to all major attractors and generators of traffic in the City of Pickering along
                 Brock Road and Whites Road;
           •     Connect easterly into Durham Region for major educational and institutional centres
                 along Highway 407, Highway 7, Taunton Road, and existing Rossland Road; and,
           •     Connect to a proposed Pickering Airport to the north of the Development Planning
                 Area.

           Minor transit corridors, on the other hand, will provide local service within the Seaton
           area. Minor transit corridors identified in the CPDP (Schedule 4) include Rossland
           Road/Sideline Road 22 and other collector and arterial roads as identified in Figure
           C7.1.

           7.1.1 ROUTE PLANNING

           Details of potential routing plans for each development phase are contained in the
           Seaton SSIS Update (May 2013) and are provided in Appendix C2. These plans were
           developed so that the majority of the development areas are within a 5-minute walk (or

The Sernas Group Inc., Stonybrook Consulting Inc.            July 2013          Master Environmental Servicing Plan Amendment - Final
SPL Beatty, Bird and Hale Limited, Earthfx Inc.               07161                               Seaton Community, City of Pickering
AMEC Earth & Environmental, R.J. Burnside                      C-51
Amos Environment + Planning
           approximately 400m) of transit service, therefore fulfilling the transit service policy set
           out in the CPDP.

7.2        SEATON GO STATION
           The CPDP (Figure C1.1) proposed a new GO Transit rail station near Taunton Road
           west of Brock Road along the CPR Belleville Subdivision. A number of constraints and
           operational issues have been identified with providing a GO service to Seaton on the
           CPR Belleville Subdivision. Until GO Transit completes further study into this matter, it
           is prudent to protect for a station location on the CPR Belleville Subdivision and three
           sites were evaluated in this MESPA.

           Two potential GO Transit rail station sites along the CPR (that are not within the NHS)
           were identified on the west side of Brock Road and a third possible station site was
           identified east of Brock Road. The three sites that were evaluated are shown in Figure
           C7.2 and are identified as the West, Central and East Sites. The constraints of the CPR
           Belleville line and these sites have been discussed with GO Transit staff. The GO rail
           tracks will be located to the south of the existing CPR tracks. The evaluation of each of
           the sites is described in Table C7.1.

                                              TABLE C7.1: POTENTIAL GO STATION SITES

           Based on the evaluation above, this assessment concluded that the East Site is the
           preferred location for a proposed Seaton GO station and should be “protected” for that
           use. It complies with the CPDP Policy 1b (page 55) “Upon identifying the station
           location(s), re-examine the abutting land-uses to ensure an appropriate mix and intensity
           of land-uses is permitted.”

7.3        REGIONAL TRANSIT SERVICE
           This section discusses other transit improvements that could contribute to reducing car
           use by residents and workers within the Seaton Community as well as southwest
           Pickering. This discussion is not limited to what is already planned, but includes a
           discussion of other potential improvements that could offer additional trip choice benefits
           to north Pickering (and locations further afield).

           7.3.1 WHITES ROAD GO STATION

           The analysis of the transit service within Seaton and the linkages to the existing urban
           areas in Pickering has determined that Whites Road and Brock Road should each
           provide higher order transit service. This conclusion is consistent with the report on the
           Region of Durham’s Long Term Transit Strategy, March 2010.

           The Brock Road transit service is included in “The Big Move” as Project #39, although
           there is no reference in that report to higher order transit on Whites Road. Consideration
           could be given to locating a second GO station where the future Seaton GO Rail service
           crosses Whites Road, which could serve Seaton as well as the existing developed areas
           of southwest Pickering although it is outside the CPDP boundary. It is also significant
           that Whites Road intersects the future 407 BRT and the northerly extension, as
           proposed by the GTAA, would connect to the main passenger terminal building of the
           future proposed Pickering Airport.

           A further benefit from a Whites Road GO Station is that parking can be provided on the
           Hydro right-of-way and reduce the need for parking at the Brock/Taunton location
           thereby increasing the development potential as required in the CPDP.




The Sernas Group Inc., Stonybrook Consulting Inc.          July 2013         Master Environmental Servicing Plan Amendment - Final
SPL Beatty, Bird and Hale Limited, Earthfx Inc.             07161                              Seaton Community, City of Pickering
AMEC Earth & Environmental, R.J. Burnside                    C-53
Amos Environment + Planning
           7.3.2 METROLINX

           The proposal to provide GO Rail service to Seaton is included in the Metrolinx report
           “The Big Move”, identified as Project 14 in Schedule 1: 15-Year Plan for the Regional
           Rapid Transit and Highway Network. Preliminary discussions with GO Transit and CPR
           identified a number of concerns, which will need to be addressed including:

           •     Rail connections to Union Station (which currently are not available),
           •     Station capacity at Union Station is not confirmed,
           •     Resolution of rail conflicts with CPR operations at Agincourt Yard,
           •     Establishing a station at Summerhill (as an alternate to Union Station),
           •     Operating a GO Rail on the CP Belleville Subdivision, and
           •     Additional structures crossing over the Rouge Valley.

           The resolution of these issues may delay the introduction of rail transit and consequently
           the transit analysis in this report has focused on bus transit including connections to the
           existing Highway 407 GO BRT, which over time will be upgraded to a separate
           Transitway, as well as the existing GO Lakeshore Rail Line and GO bus service on
           Highway 401 with a focus on connections to Scarborough in general and TTC routes in
           particular.

           ”The Big Move” Schedule 1 conceptually shows the intersection of three proposed transit
           lines (Havelock [GO] regional rail, Highway 407 BTR, and York Region’s VIVA bus
           service), at Highway 407 and Locust Hill, approximately 5 km west of Whites Road.

8.0        ACTIVE TRANSPORTATION
           The active transportation system includes the trail system developed in “Seaton Natural
           Heritage System Management Plan and Master Trails Plan”, (NHS/Trails Plan) October
           2008 including on-road 1.5m bike lanes along the Collector roads, 3m asphalt paths
           within the right-of-way of the Type C Arterial roads, as well as a network of 3m paths
           through the NHS linking the Community Facilities and neighbourhoods. Figure C8.1
           illustrates the Active Transportation Network as developed in “NHS/Trails Plan.” The
           trail locations shown on Figure C8.1 have been modified from that shown in the
           “NHS/Trails Plan”, and reflect the Neighbourhood Plans prepared by the City of
           Pickering and also that shown in OPA 22. As these relocated trails did not receive the
           same level of site specific investigations regarding natural heritage and natural hazards
           (including topography), as occurred as part of the preparation of the Master Trail Plan,
           further appropriate field investigations are required. Prior to the construction of the trails
           systems within the NHS, an appropriate EA for the trails will be prepared, by the public
           authority that has determined that it will construct the trails. The Developer Land
           Owners of Seaton will be responsible only for construction of the Trailheads, which will
           not require an EA.

           The CPDP mandated consideration of active transportation choices including the Seaton
           trail system, on-road bicycle lanes, paths within road rights-of-way and paths within the
           NHS linking neighbourhoods as developed in the NHS/Trails Plan. The active
           transportation system was designed to provide connections and linkages among the
           Seaton Community neighbourhoods to reduce reliance on automobiles and thereby

The Sernas Group Inc., Stonybrook Consulting Inc.   July 2013        Master Environmental Servicing Plan Amendment - Final
SPL Beatty, Bird and Hale Limited, Earthfx Inc.      07161                             Seaton Community, City of Pickering
AMEC Earth & Environmental, R.J. Burnside             C-54
Amos Environment + Planning
           reduce environmental impacts. The trail plan identifies locations for trail system through
           NHS to minimize potential random use.

           For the active transportation choices, Seaton roads will be designed with dedicated on-
           road bicycle lanes or multi-use trails in the right-of-way to service residents of the
           development areas. In order to implement these choices, it is recommended that each
           plan of subdivision review the NHS/Trails Plan and particularly the bike routes to
           determine whether there is a trail section proposed along or across the road to ensure
           that road design will accommodate trail requirements (e.g. underpass design;
           intersection design; continuous trail section).

9.0        ALTERNATE INITIATIVES
           Travel Demand Management (TDM) is the term used to describe initiatives, policies and
           recommendations to reduce the public’s dependence on the car and use alternate
           modes of transportation (transit, carpooling, walking, cycling, active transportation) which
           will contribute to the reduction of overall congestion and parking requirements. TDM
           measures can include but are not limited to the following:

           •     Reliable transit,
           •     Live – work communities,
           •     Employer initiatives through flexible working hours, compressed work weeks, and
                 telecommuting,
           •     Employer incentives to encourage users of other modes of transportation,
           •     Bicycle storage facilities,
           •     Shower facilities for cyclists and active commuters (run, walk),
           •     Encourage higher auto occupancy with carpool networks, such as Smart Commute’s
                 Carpool Zone and providing priority or convenient parking locations,
           •     Encourage auto-share, such as Zipcar / AutoShare,
           •     Minimize available parking to promote other transportation modes and to maximize
                 shared-use parking, and
           •     Increase awareness of alternative transportation modes through education and
                 advertising.

           From the list above, one can see that TDM measures can be physical elements as well
           as non-physical, such as operational programs and behavioural characteristics.

           Potentially, residents of the development do not need to own a vehicle for transportation
           – they can take transit to work, shop, or leisure – recreation activities. The residents can
           ride-share with friends and co-workers (carpools) or belong to an auto-share club. The
           City may consider implementing policies or zoning by-laws to ensure reserved areas for
           bicycle storage is provided in multi-residential and public buildings.

           The Seaton plan includes bike lanes, bike paths and trails in the NHS which provide
           alternatives (walking, running, cycling) to using a vehicle to get to places within the
           community. In summary, the possibilities exist in Seaton to measurably reduce auto-
           dependency and auto-driver trips over similar new communities since all or a
           combination of these TDM practices is planned to be implemented.


The Sernas Group Inc., Stonybrook Consulting Inc.   July 2013      Master Environmental Servicing Plan Amendment - Final
SPL Beatty, Bird and Hale Limited, Earthfx Inc.      07161                           Seaton Community, City of Pickering
AMEC Earth & Environmental, R.J. Burnside             C-55
Amos Environment + Planning
10.0 CONFORMITY WITH MEA CLASS EA PROCESS
           As detailed in Chapter A, Sections 1.0 and 9.0, the MESP Terms of Reference require
           that this MESPA meets the requirements of the MEA Class EA process, specifically the
           first two phases with regard to confirming the road and transit network requirements as
           set out in the CPDP. A requirement of the MEA Class EA process is to establish the
           capital costs of the works in order to establish which schedule applies. If the capital
           costs of the works were estimated to exceed $2.7 million in 2009 (the year that the initial
           cost estimates were made for the purpose of selecting a Class EA Schedule, in
           accordance with MEA Class EA requirements) then the project is identified as Schedule
           ‘C’ and will require Phases 3 and 4 of the MEA Class EA process. Please note that the
           Municipal Engineers Association (MEA) updates its road project cost limits yearly (see
           www.municipalclassea.ca) with instructions that "the Cost Limit threshold in place at the
           time a project is initiated shall be the cost threshold used to determine the applicable
           Schedule and process to be followed throughout until the completion of the Class EA
           process".

           In accordance with the definitions of costs in the MEA Class EA the capital costs of the
           Type C Arterial and Collector roads, including oversizing costs, were estimated and are
           presented here in Table C10.1.

           From Table C10.1 the following road projects have been identified as being subject to
           Schedule ‘C’ of the MEA Class EA:

           •     Road I - North-South Type C Arterial (Sideline 24) ($6.77 million)
           •     Road IV - East-West Special Type C Arterial ($5.77 million)
           •     Road VI - East-West Employment Collector ($4.5 million)

           As a result of discussions with MTO, the Seaton Landowners Group has confirmed that
           extensions to Sideline 26/Whites Road and Sideline 22/Rossland Road will not be
           permitted to have intersections between Highway 7 and the westbound ramp termini of
           Highway 407 ETR. Consequently, a continuous east-west collector road in these
           locations is not feasible. The road network to serve the Prestige Employment uses in
           this area will be in the form of local roads with connections to Highway 7. The
           alignments for these roads will be determined by the lot configurations of the
           employment uses, phasing of employment uses and the intersection spacing
           requirements for Highway 7. As a result, these roads, previously identified as collector
           roads, will no longer be subject to the Municipal Class EA (i.e. they will be Schedule A)
           and their locations will be determined via the Planning Act approvals process for the
           employment lands.

           Table C10.2 presents the next steps to be undertaken for the three City roads identified
           as Schedule ‘C’ projects.

                       TABLE C10.2: NEXT STEPS IN MEA CLASS EA PROCESS (Phases 3 and 4)

               Step                                             Phases 3 and 4
               1.          Identify alternative design concepts for the preferred alternative
               2.          Detailed inventory of natural, social and economic environment
               3.          Identify impact of alternative design concepts on environment and mitigation
               4.          Evaluate alternative design concepts and select recommended design
               5.          Public Information Centre Consultation with public and agencies
               6.          Select preferred design
               7.          Preliminary finalization of preferred design
               8.          Complete Environmental Study Report
               9.          Notice of Study Completion for a 30-day public review period
               10.         Objectors may appeal to the Minister of the Environment (requesting Part II Order)

                                                                    distance of ~2.8 km (see Appendix C6-A, Table 1, crossings #16 to #21                                     and

    #                           Road                 Type                                           Description                                          and 4              Triggers

                                                                •   Mitigation measures for this road include: shift road north so only 10m of                             Employment
                                                                    the northern edge of the NHS is affected; relocate the east segment                                      Phases)
                                                                    (crossing #21) to improve stream crossing location and reduce impacts to
                                                                    wetland and woodland units; require design to minimize potential for wildlife
                                                                    movement from NHS to road and areas to the north.
                                                                •   Key considerations in selecting this route included:
                                                                    o Reduction in impact to NHS.
                                                                    o Need to serve employment lands.
                                                                    o Linkages to roads: North Road to Rossland Road Extension.
                                                                •   MNR, MEI, ORC, TRCA, and City of Pickering provided input in the
                                                                    proposed alignment (at meeting on June 14, 2011 (minutes provided in
                                                                    Chapter H).
      VII             East-West Collector           Collector   •   This collector will serve the development areas north of Taunton Road.                  No             2015 – 2020
                           (South)                              •   The right-of-way and pavement width will accommodate transit.                                            (Seaton
                                                                •   This road crosses one stream corridor and one location with no channel                                  Phase 1)
                                                                    within the NHS, for a total distance of ~185m (see Appendix C6-A, Table
                                                                    1, crossings #13, #14 for NHS conditions and recommendations re NHS).
                                                                •   Mitigation measures for this Road include: open bottom channel crossing
                                                                    structure that as a minimum accommodate the 100 year erosion limit,
                                                                    address hydraulic requirements and design to promote wildlife linkage;
                                                                    provision of culvert for linkage for amphibians for non-channel crossing,
                                                                    and surface road design to minimize potential vehicle-wildlife collisions.
                                                                •   Key considerations in selecting this route included:
                                                                    o Shift south of westerly NHS crossing reduces impact to
                                                                        wetland/woodland.
                                                                    o Overall reduction in impact to NHS.

 Seaton Staged Servicing and Implementation Strategy, revised May 2013 (Seaton SSIS)




The Sernas Group Inc., Stonybrook Consulting Inc.                                         July 2013                                        Master Environmental Servicing Plan Amendment - Final
SPL Beatty, Bird and Hale Limited, Earthfx Inc.                                            07161                                                             Seaton Community, City of Pickering
AMEC Earth & Environmental, R.J. Burnside                                                   C-63
Amos Environment + Planning
12.0 RECOMMENDATIONS
           The recommendations of this MESPA with regards to transportation are as follows:

           City of Pickering

           •     City road alignment modifications are recommended as presented in Chapter C,
                 Section 11.0.
           •     Work with GO Transit to protect the East Site (as described in Chapter C, Section
                 7.2 Seaton Go Station) as the preferred location for a proposed Seaton GO station.
           •     City transfer to the Region the jurisdiction of Whitevale Road between Brock Road
                 and the Realigned Whitevale Road.
           •     Ensure the construction of the City roads according to the phasing contained in the
                 revised Seaton SSIS, May 2013.

           Region of Durham

           •     Ensure the construction of the Regional roads according to the phasing contained in
                 the revised Seaton SSIS, May 2013.
           •     Coordinate Whites Road construction with 407ETR at the interchange.
           •     Download to the City the existing Brock Road between the north and south limits of
                 the realigned Brock Road.

           MTO

           •     Consider transfer of Highway 7 to the Regions of Durham and York, so that the MEA
                 Class EA study can begin for the widening of Highway 7 within each Region’s
                 jurisdiction.

           407ETR

           •     Implement the recommendations with regard to the proposed Whites Road and
                 Rossland Road interchanges with 407ETR as set out in this study and the revised
                 Seaton SSIS, May 2013: that the Whites Road interchange be constructed first and
                 be operational by no later than 2018 and that the Rossland Road interchange
                 construction be constructed (when justified by traffic demand) however no later than
                 2028.
           •     Obtain MOE approval for an Environmental Assessment Addendum to 407 East EA
                 to update Whites Road and Rossland Road interchange locations.

           Metrolinx / GO Transit

           •     GO Transit to provide rail service along the Belleville Subdivision and protect for a
                 station (preferably not a terminus) in the southeast quadrant of Brock Road and
                 Taunton Road and potentially a second station located at Whites Road.
           •     Metrolinx to pursue approvals for transit locations along 407ETR at Whites Road,
                 Rossland Road Extension and York Durham Line. (As noted in Chapter C, Section
                 3.3.1, due to environmental and cultural constraints in the vicinity of the proposed
                 transit station at Brock Road, Whites Road and also Rossland Road Extension

The Sernas Group Inc., Stonybrook Consulting Inc.   July 2013       Master Environmental Servicing Plan Amendment - Final
SPL Beatty, Bird and Hale Limited, Earthfx Inc.      07161                            Seaton Community, City of Pickering
AMEC Earth & Environmental, R.J. Burnside             C-64
Amos Environment + Planning
                 locations, it may be necessary to advance construction of a transit station at York
                 Durham Line.
           •     A transit station at Whites Road will require EA Act approval.

           General

           •     All parties to examine the ongoing results of the SSIS and MESPA recommended
                 monitoring. Determine if changes are necessary resulting from the implementation
                 of various projects or phasing. At each Phase, the monitoring results will be
                 considered and may be incorporated into the design of each City road alignment.

           Seaton Landowners Group

           •     Conduct Environmental Study Reports for the following City road projects in
                 accordance with Phases 3 and 4 of the MEA Class EA planning process:
                 o Road I – North-south Type C Arterial (Sideline Road 24),
                 o Road IV – East-West Special Type C Arterial (North), and
                 o Road VI – Employment Collector.
           •     Design NHS crossings in accordance with site specific mitigation measures, as
                 addressed in Chapter C, Section 6.4.2 and Chapter C, Section 11.0. For all NHS
                 crossings the ‘Design Considerations For City Roads Through Seaton NHS’ as set
                 out in Table C6.13 must be addressed.
           •     Adopt the recommendations with regard to Endangered Species presented in
                 Chapter C, Section 6.2.
           •     Monitor any additional species at risk identified by MNR in the vicinity of City roads
                 and ensure that a MNR permit or an update to the Overall Benefit Plan or Mitigation
                 Plan where appropriate (see Chapter E) be addressed in accordance with the
                 Endangered Species Act.
           •     Obtain, where required, appropriate permits from the TRCA prior to construction of
                 City roads.
           •     Proceed in accordance with the framework for fisheries compensation as provided in
                 Chapter F for all stream crossings, where there is potential for harmful alteration,
                 disruption or destruction or disturbance (HADD) at stream crossings, under the
                 Federal Fisheries Act. Note that these provisions may be in addition to any
                 requirements associated with the Redside Dace Overall Benefit Plan or Mitigation
                 Plan where applicable.

Ministry of Transportation
Durham/Toronto/York Transportation Study




inability to provide new roadway links through the Rouge Park as a result of current Provincial Policy (“no
new roads in the Rouge Park”). This policy generates challenges to the development of future transit
corridors linking Durham, York and Toronto. As noted earlier, the Study Area also lacks any significant transit
service. Attempts to provide transit service to the CPDP area must be undertaken in conjunction with arterial
roadway improvements in the area to permit a “transit first” plan with any chance of success.

To address the other transportation problems within the Study Area and the future travel demands of
residents and employees in the Central Pickering Area, a number of structural and non-structural
improvements are required. The infrastructure, service, and planning considerations identified in this report
should be reviewed as a package of system improvements. In this regard, there are several initiatives, both
structural and non-structural, which are considered early priorities or “quick starts” in order to facilitate growth
and provide opportunities for greater mode choice and reduced reliance on the automobile.

Transportation strategies identified in the early phases of implementation should promote a “transit first”
approach to transit service for the Central Pickering area. Key initiatives such as the provision of transit
services on Taunton Road/Steeles Avenue, 407 and Highway 7 should be coordinated with the respective
road network improvements to enable early implementation of a “transit first” approach. Without many of
these infrastructure improvements the ability to make early and meaningful transit service available in the
Study Area is severely hindered. Without these improvements it must be expected that current modal
patterns (low transit use) will prevail and ultimately become entrenched in the urban fabric of the future
community resulting in the need for further roadway infrastructure improvements and less emphasis on
transit service.

It is worth noting that the structural and non-structural improvements identified in this report can not alone
guarantee a “transit first” plan for the CPDP area – there is a need for a transformational philosophical
approach by the approving authorities in the planning and implementation of the community. Approving the
most appropriate land use, densities and development staging, including the early development of
employment lands, will be critical to support the transportation initiatives recommended herein. Approving
“business as usual” low density residential development will not result in a transit supportive plan even when
combined with the transportation initiatives described in this report.

The transit improvements recommended in support of the CPDP plan are summarized in Table A and shown
in Exhibit 1 below.

                              Table A: Transit Infrastructure Implementation Plan

Facility/Service             Limits             Nature of             Timing/Schedule          Jurisdiction
                                              Improvement
Durham Region
GO Rail Service        Through Study     GO Rail service              Coordinated with      Metrolinx
– Seaton Line          Area              expansion on CPR             development of        RTP – 15 Year
Expansion                                Belleville subdivision to    the Study Area        Plan (Project #14:
                                         Seaton with new station                            Seaton to Union

DTY Study                                                                                                        - iv -
       Ministry of Transportation
       Durham/Toronto/York Transportation Study




       purposes only to provide an indication of the level of initial capital and ongoing operational costs associated
       with transit services within the CPDP.

       Capital costs for the conventional services described above could be in the order of $97 -$105 Million (2008
       dollars). These costs do not include property costs but include the following:

               •   Conventional transit vehicles;
               •   Community buses;
               •   Specialized vehicles;
               •   Communications and other ITS equipment;
               •   Transit maintenance and garage facilities;
               •   Bus stops and stations;
               •   Bus Shelters;
               •   Transit stations and park’n’ride facilities along 407 East (Sidelines 22 and 26 and Brock Road)

       Net operating costs for the conventional services described above could be in the order of $12-$15 Million
       per annum (2008 dollars).

       These costs do not include capital or operating cost estimates associated with the following.
          • Infrastructure and services to be provided and operated by GO Transit;
          • Any services that may be provided by York Region or TTC directly to the CPDP area.

       The roadway improvements recommended in support of the CPDP plan are summarized in Table B and
       shown in Exhibit 2 below.

        Durham/Toronto/York Area Transportation Study (DTY Study)                                Long Term Transit Strategy

        The DTY Study was undertaken by the MTO with the participation of the Region of          The Long Term Transit Strategy (LTTS) is a comprehensive plan that identifies
        Durham, the Region of York and the City of Toronto. It was completed in August           transportation/transit challenges and opportunities in Durham Region. It was
        2009. The study not only addressed the external transportation linkages for the          prepared by Durham Region Transit (DRT) in March 2010. The LTTS provides a long
        Seaton Urban area, but also addressed the needs based on a study area that               term regional transit strategy for Durham Region that considers multi-modal
        included much of the Pickering and Ajax urban areas as well as portions of east          transportation alternatives as they relate to, and impact transit.
        Markham and the northeast portion of the City of Toronto. The primary purpose of
        the study was to identify a possible framework for transportation infrastructure         In Seaton, the LTTS identifies Sideline 26, Sideline 22 (Rossland Road) and Brock
        investment by government and key transportation infrastructure improvements              Road as key north-south bus transit routes as well as Highway 7 and Taunton Road
        required of each of the four jurisdictions in order to address the short, medium and     as key east-west routes with the latter protecting for future Light Rail Transit.
        long term inter-regional road and transit needs of the large study area.

            This report is considered by the Province as advisory and for consideration.       The development phasing strategy was determined based on an annual single

December 2011, Revised May 2013                                                                                                  Proposed Staged Servicing and Implementation Strategy | 4
01097                                                                                                                               Seaton Urban Area | Central Pickering Development Plan
        Figure C, Development Phasing Plan, identifies the limits of the Phase 1 Living Area
        which will contain up to 9,800 SDEs and the Phase 1 Employment Area. This area
        represents a logical distribution of the 9,800 SDEs in a manner which makes efficient
        use of the required road and servicing extensions. This area also includes the lands
        required to provide for commercial uses, schools, parks, recreation complexes,
        libraries, police and emergency service needs of the projected population of Phase 1
        in convenient and accessible locations. The location of the initial Phase 1
        Employment Area is located to align with road and servicing extensions through the
        central corridor of Seaton. This location provides the earliest development
        opportunity to closely coincide with development of the Phase 1 Living Areas.

        The subsequent phase(s) of development will expand from the core areas
        established in Phase 1. They will also provide the additional facilities required to
        meet the needs of the additional population added to achieve the initial build-out
        target of 61,000 persons in Seaton.

01097                                                                                              Seaton Urban Area | Central Pickering Development Plan
